Screen.title: TopScreen
Screen.Label: ---------- Mouse Button 1 click on field to change ----------

Help.Tip: Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PROCESSDEFAULTS
Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
 
 Default = SYSTEM
 Allowed = SYSTEM
 Allowed = PROJECT
 Allowed = USER
 SYSTEM defaults are the defaults listed in the CPS documentation.
 
 PROJECT defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as Project
 Default button.
 
 USER defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as User Default
 button.

Help.Tip: Output all specified image traces?
Help.Text:
kdmig - ALL_OUT
Output all specified image traces?
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES  (Output all specified image traces.)
 Allowed = NO   (Output only image traces corresponding to input traces.)
 If ALL_OUT=YES, the output will be all the image traces specified by the
 output grid parameters including those that do not correspond to input
 traces.
 
 Output of image traces may be further restricted if the SPARSE option is
 turned on.
 
 ALL_OUT should be set to YES when generating broadcast patterns.

Help.Tip: Should KDMIG produce a single image regardless of input offset?
Help.Text:
kdmig - ONE_IMAGE
Should KDMIG produce a single image regardless of input offset?
 
 Default = YES for 3D, NO for 2D
 Allowed = YES/NO
 If ONE_IMAGE = YES, then a single image is produced regardless of input
 offsets.  Header word 6 for output traces is set to the center value of the
 offset bin associated with the offset of the first input trace.  The imaging
 aperture is determined by this same offset bin.
 
 If ONE_IMAGE = NO, then a separate image is created for each offset bin
 occupied by an input trace.  In this case a new image is created each time an
 input trace occupies a different offset bin.

Help.Tip: Define image groups by header word HDR_GROUP.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_GROUP
Define image groups by header word HDR_GROUP.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO  KMIG will not define groups by header word HDR_GROUP.
 Allowed = YES KMIG will     define groups by header word HDR_GROUP.

Help.Tip: Header word to define groups.
Help.Text:
kdmig - HDR_GROUP
Header word to define groups.
 
 Default = 55
 Allowed = 1-64 KMIG will define groups by header word HDR_GROUP.

Help.Tip: Choice of output type desired.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_OUTPUT
Choice of output type desired.
 
 Default = IMAGE
 Allowed = IMAGE  (Production output of the normal migration image.)
 Allowed = VEL    (Diagnostic output of the migration velocity field.)
 Allowed = TIME   (Diagnostic output of the two-way travel time.)
 Allowed = AA     (Diagnostic output of the anti-aliasing coefficients.)
 Allowed = AMPL   (Diagnostic output of the migration amplitude.)

Help.Tip: Whether to use a 2D or 3D algorithm.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DIMENSION
Whether to use a 2D or 3D algorithm.
 
 Default = 3D
 Allowed = 2D
 Allowed = 3D
 If DIMENSION = 2D, then a 2D algorithm is used, all "X" parameters pertain to
 the inline direction, all "Y" parameters are ignored and the aperture has
 extent in the inline direction only.  Only one 2D line can be migrated at
 once.
 
 If DIMENSION = 3D, then a 3D algorithm is used and both "X" parameters and
 "Y" parameters are active.

Help.Tip: Interpolate input to DT_INTERP sample interval before imaging.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DT_INTERP
Interpolate input to DT_INTERP sample interval before imaging.
 
 Default = 0.001
 Allowed = DT >= real > 0.0
 Interpolate input traces to DT_INTERP sample interval, in seconds, before
 imaging.  DT_INTERP must divide input DT evenly.
 
 Input trace samples are interpolated (if necessary) to a sample interval of
 DT_INTERP seconds prior to imaging to insure adequate resolution of the
 output image.  Normally 0.001 or 0.002 seconds is adequate.

Help.Tip: Remove the image files when the job is completed.
Help.Text:
kdmig - REMOVE_IMAGE
Remove the image files when the job is completed.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES (KDMIG will remove the image files at the end of the job.)
 Allowed = NO  (KDMIG will not remove the image files at the end of the job.)

Help.Tip: Recover the image files from a fialed job.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RECOVER_IMAGE
Recover the image files from a fialed job.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES KMIG will recover the image files from a failed job.
 Allowed = NO  KMIG will operate as normal.

Help.Tip: Vertical scale factor used to map image to output traces.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DEP_SCALE
Vertical scale factor used to map image to output traces.
 
 Default = 1000.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 DEPTH_SCALE is used to scale the vertical image dimension to output traces.
 
                Output TSTRT = DEP_INIT / DEP_SCALE.
                Output DT = DEP_INC / DEP_SCALE.

Help.Tip: Type of sum reduce at output.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_SUM_REDUCE
Type of sum reduce at output.
 
 Default = GLOBAL
 Allowed = LOCAL

Help.Tip: Root name of image file names.
Help.Text:
kdmig - ROOT_IMAGE
Root name of image file names.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character
 KDMIG places image traces for each CPU in a separate temporary disk file.
 If ROOT_IMAGE is other than NONE, KDMIG will construct the image files
 using the pathname prefix ROOT_IMAGE.
 
 If ROOT_IMAGE = NONE, KDMIG will construct the image files using a default.

Help.Tip: Stack the output traces.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_STACK
Stack the output traces.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES
 Allowed = NO
 If OPT_STACK=YES  KMIG will     stack the output traces from all pes.
 If OPT_STACK=NO   KMIG will not stack the output traces from all pes.
 If OPT_STACK=NO and OPT_TROT=LAST
 KMIG will write the image traces from each pe to a separate FILE
 whose name will be defined by ROOT_TROT with the pe index and '.trc' apended.
 KMIG will also write a list of those file names and the number of
 traces written to the file to an ascii file.
 whose name will be defined by ROOT_TROT with '.list' apended.

Help.Tip: Write output to trot file every NUM_TROT traces.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_TROT
Write output to trot file every NUM_TROT traces.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES
 Allowed = NO
 Allowed = LAST
 If OPT_TROT=YES  KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces.
 If OPT_TROT=NO   KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 If OPT_TROT=LAST KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces and after the last input trace.
 KMIG will print a banner starting with kmig_image_trot stating the number
 of input traces contained in the image at output time.
 Header word HDR_FOLD is set to the number of input traces in the image.

Help.Tip: Write output to trot file every NUM_TROT traces.
Help.Text:
kdmig - NUM_TROT
Write output to trot file every NUM_TROT traces.
 
 Default = 999999
 Allowed = INT>0
 If OPT_TROT=YES  KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces.
 If OPT_TROT=NO   KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 If OPT_TROT=LAST KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces and after the last input trace.
 KMIG will print a banner starting with kmig_image_trot stating the number
 of input traces contained in the image at output time.
 Header word HDR_FOLD is set to the number of input traces in the image.

Help.Tip: Select file name.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SELECT_ROOT_TROT
Select file name.
 
 If OPT_TROT=YES  KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces.
 If OPT_TROT=NO   KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 If OPT_TROT=LAST KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces and after the last input trace.
 KMIG will print a banner starting with kmig_image_trot stating the number
 of input traces contained in the image at output time.
 Header word HDR_FOLD is set to the number of input traces in the image.

Help.Tip: Output file name.
Help.Text:
kdmig - ROOT_TROT
Output file name.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character
 If OPT_TROT=YES  KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces.
 If OPT_TROT=NO   KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 If OPT_TROT=LAST KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces and after the last input trace.
 KMIG will print a banner starting with kmig_image_trot stating the number
 of input traces contained in the image at output time.
 Header word HDR_FOLD is set to the number of input traces in the image.

Help.Tip: Header word for the x-coordinate of the output image volume.
Help.Text:
kdmig - HDR_X
Header word for the x-coordinate of the output image volume.
 
 Default = 7
 Allowed = 7, 8, 17, 18
 Allowed values for HDR_X and HDR_Y respectively are (7, 8); (8, 7); (17, 18);
 and (18, 17).  No other combinations are permitted.

Help.Tip: Header word for the y-coordinate of the output image volume.
Help.Text:
kdmig - HDR_Y
Header word for the y-coordinate of the output image volume.
 
 Default = 8
 Allowed = 7, 8, 17, 18
 Allowed values for HDR_X and HDR_Y respectively are (7, 8); (8, 7); (17, 18);
 and (18, 17).  No other combinations are permitted.

Help.Tip: Sort order of input and output data.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SORT_ORDER
Sort order of input and output data.
 
 Default = X_IS_FAST
 Allowed = X_IS_FAST
 Allowed = Y_IS_FAST
 If SORT_ORDER = X_IS_FAST, then HDR_X is the more rapidly changing header
 word and HDR_Y is the more slowly changing header word for both input and
 output.
 
 If SORT_ORDER = Y_IS_FAST, then HDR_Y is the more rapidly changing header
 word and HDR_X is the more slowly changing header word for both input and
 output.

Help.Tip: Extra image traces in the x-direction to keep in memory.
Help.Text:
kdmig - X_SORT_WIDTH
Extra image traces in the x-direction to keep in memory.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real >= 0.
 If SORT_ORDER = Y_IS_FAST, kdmig will keep (X_SORT_WIDTH / X_INC) + 1
 extra image traces in the x-direction in memory.  This allows the use of
 super sorts to minimize travel time table swapping.
 
 Active only if DIMENSION = 3D.

Help.Tip: Extra image traces in the y-direction to keep in memory.
Help.Text:
kdmig - Y_SORT_WIDTH
Extra image traces in the y-direction to keep in memory.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real >= 0.
 If SORT_ORDER = X_IS_FAST, kdmig will keep (Y_SORT_WIDTH / Y_INC) + 1
 extra image traces in the y-direction in memory.  This allows the use of
 super sorts to minimize travel time table swapping.
 
 Active only if DIMENSION = 3D.

Help.Tip: First value of HDR_X in the output image volume.
Help.Text:
kdmig - X_INIT
First value of HDR_X in the output image volume.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: First value of HDR_Y in the output image volume.
Help.Text:
kdmig - Y_INIT
First value of HDR_Y in the output image volume.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: Depth of the first sample in the output image traces.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DEP_INIT
Depth of the first sample in the output image traces.
 
 Default = compute
 Allowed = real
 Depth of the first sample in the output image traces, in feet or meters.

Help.Tip: Value at the center of the first offset bin, in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OFF_INIT
Value at the center of the first offset bin, in feet or meters.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 KDMIG uses header word 6 to determine an input trace's offset.

Help.Tip: Increment between HDR_X values in the output image volume.
Help.Text:
kdmig - X_INC
Increment between HDR_X values in the output image volume.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Increment between HDR_Y values in the output image volume.
Help.Text:
kdmig - Y_INC
Increment between HDR_Y values in the output image volume.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Depth sample interval in the output image traces.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DEP_INC
Depth sample interval in the output image traces.
 
 Default = compute
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 Depth sample interval, in feet or meters, in the output image traces.

Help.Tip: Increment of offset values between offset bins.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OFF_INC
Increment of offset values between offset bins.
 
 Default = 200
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 Increment of offset values between offset bins, in feet or meters.  OFF_INC is
 also equal to the width of an offset bin.

Help.Tip: Last value of HDR_X in the output image volume.
Help.Text:
kdmig - X_LAST
Last value of HDR_X in the output image volume.
 
 Default = 100
 Allowed = real >= X_INIT

Help.Tip: Last value of HDR_Y in the output image volume.
Help.Text:
kdmig - Y_LAST
Last value of HDR_Y in the output image volume.
 
 Default = 100
 Allowed = real >= Y_INIT

Help.Tip: Depth of the last sample in the output image traces.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DEP_LAST
Depth of the last sample in the output image traces.
 
 Default = compute
 Allowed = real >= DEP_INIT
 Depth of the last sample in the output image traces, in feet or meters.

Help.Tip: Value at the center of the last offset bin, in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OFF_LAST
Value at the center of the last offset bin, in feet or meters.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real >= OFF_INIT

Help.Tip: Total number of HDR_X values in the output image volume.
Help.Text:
kdmig - X_TOT
Total number of HDR_X values in the output image volume.
 
 Default = 101
 Allowed = int > 0

Help.Tip: Total number of HDR_Y values in the output image volume.
Help.Text:
kdmig - Y_TOT
Total number of HDR_Y values in the output image volume.
 
 Default = 101
 Allowed = int > 0

Help.Tip: Total number of samples in the output image traces.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DEP_TOT
Total number of samples in the output image traces.
 
 Default = NDPT
 Allowed = int > 0

Help.Tip: Total number of offset bins.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OFF_TOT
Total number of offset bins.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int > 0

Help.Tip: Variable depth step option.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_STEP
Variable depth step option.
 
 Default = CONSTANT
 Allowed = CONSTANT - use a constant depth step size of DEP_INC
 Allowed = VARIABLE - use defined arrays of step size - depth - frequency

Help.Tip: What method for interpolating output traces.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_OUT_INT
What method for interpolating output traces.
 
 Default = LINEAR
 Allowed = LINEAR   (Use linear   interpolation for output traces. )
 Allowed = LAGRANGE (Use lagrange interpolation for output traces. )
 Allowed = NEAREST  (Use nearest  interpolation for output traces. )
 Allowed = NONE     (Use no       interpolation for output traces. )

Help.Tip: Half length of output trace interpolation operator.
Help.Text:
kdmig - LEN_OUT_INT
Half length of output trace interpolation operator.
 
 Default = 10
 Allowed = int>0
 When OPT_OUT_INT=LAGRANGE the output trace is interpolation from the
 image trace using a lagrange operator whose length to either side is
 LEN_OUT_INT * output time or depth samples

Help.Tip: Depth values for variable depth increment.
Help.Text:
kdmig - STEP_DEP
Depth values for variable depth increment.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)

Help.Tip: Depth increment values at STEP_DEP.
Help.Text:
kdmig - STEP_DEP_INC
Depth increment values at STEP_DEP.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)

Help.Tip: Whether to use sparse output.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_SPARSE
Whether to use sparse output.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO      (Do not use sparse output.)
 Allowed = YES     (Use sparse output.)

Help.Tip: First value of HDR_X in the sparse output.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SP_X_INIT
First value of HDR_X in the sparse output.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real (array)
 SP_X parameters are linked arrays with each row defining additional output.

Help.Tip: Increment between HDR_X values in the sparse output.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SP_X_INC
Increment between HDR_X values in the sparse output.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0 (array)
 SP_X parameters are linked arrays with each row defining additional output.

Help.Tip: Last value of HDR_X in the sparse output.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SP_X_LAST
Last value of HDR_X in the sparse output.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real >= SP_X_INIT (array)
 SP_X parameters are linked arrays with each row defining additional output.

Help.Tip: Total number of HDR_X values in the sparse output.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SP_X_TOT
Total number of HDR_X values in the sparse output.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = int > 0 (array)
 SP_X parameters are linked arrays with each row defining additional output.

Help.Tip: First value of HDR_Y in the sparse output.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SP_Y_INIT
First value of HDR_Y in the sparse output.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real (array)
 SP_Y parameters are linked arrays with each row defining additional output.

Help.Tip: Increment between HDR_Y values in the sparse output.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SP_Y_INC
Increment between HDR_Y values in the sparse output.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0 (array)
 SP_Y parameters are linked arrays with each row defining additional output.

Help.Tip: Last value of HDR_Y in the sparse output.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SP_Y_LAST
Last value of HDR_Y in the sparse output.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real >= SP_Y_INIT (array)
 SP_Y parameters are linked arrays with each row defining additional output.

Help.Tip: Total number of HDR_Y values in the sparse output.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SP_Y_TOT
Total number of HDR_Y values in the sparse output.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = int > 0 (array)
 SP_Y parameters are linked arrays with each row defining additional output.

Help.Tip: Whether to use polygon arrays, polygon file or no polygon.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_POLY
Whether to use polygon arrays, polygon file or no polygon.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = NONE
 Allowed = ARRAY_POLY
 Allowed = PATH_POLY
 If OPT_POLY = NONE, then no polygon restriction will be used.
 
 If OPT_POLY = ARRAY_POLY, then define polygons by arrays on GUI (X_POLY,
 Y_POLY and ID_POLY).
 
 If OPT_POLY = PATH_POLY, then define polygons by polygon file whose pathname
 is entered in PATH_POLY.

Help.Tip: Array of x-coordinate polygon vertex values.
Help.Text:
kdmig - X_POLY
Array of x-coordinate polygon vertex values.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real (array)
 Array of x-coordinate polygon vertex values linked with Y_POLY and ID_POLY.

Help.Tip: Array of y-coordinate polygon vertex values.
Help.Text:
kdmig - Y_POLY
Array of y-coordinate polygon vertex values.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real (array)
 Array of y-coordinate polygon vertex values linked with X_POLY and ID_POLY.

Help.Tip: Array of polygon identifiers.
Help.Text:
kdmig - ID_POLY
Array of polygon identifiers.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = int (array)
 Array of polygon identifiers linked with X_POLY and ID_POLY.  All vertex
 values linked with the same ID_POLY value pertain to the same polygon.
 Different polygons must have different ID_POLY values.  All array entries
 associated with the same polygon must be consecutive.

Help.Tip: polygon path name for immediately loading polygon to gui.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SELECT_PATH_POLY_LOAD
polygon path name for immediately loading polygon to gui.

Help.Tip: Pathname for polygon file to load immediately to gui.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PATH_POLY_LOAD
Pathname for polygon file to load immediately to gui.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = char
 
 Polygon files for this option are ascii files whose first three columns
 carry the same information as X_POLY, Y_POLY and ID_POLY, respectively.
 Any columns beyond three are ignored. The third column for ID_POLY is
 optional. If not present, the ID_POLY is set to the value of 1 for all
 vertices. Values is the three columns should be separated by spaces.
 
 If successfully opened and processed the polygon vertex values are
 immediately entered into the X_POLY, Y_POLY and ID_POLY arrays on the
 gui. These can then be saved in the work file. The name of the file
 associated with these coordinates is NOT saved in the work file and
 is only read in the gui stage.
 
 Currently, there is a limit of 100 vertices that can be read in this
 manner.
 
 NOTE: parameter OPT_POLY must be set to option ARRAY_POLY to use
       the polygon read in using this option.

Help.Tip: polygon path name.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SELECT_PATH_POLY
polygon path name.

Help.Tip: Pathname for polygon file.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PATH_POLY
Pathname for polygon file.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = char
 Polygon files are ascii files whose first three columns carry the same
 information as X_POLY, Y_POLY and ID_POLY respectively and can have an
 optional fourth column carrying header value information.  Only the first
 three columns are used by KDMIG.
 
 The SETPOLY CPS process requires polygon files with four columns.  Files
 prepared for SETPOLY can be used with KDMIG, although the fourth column will
 be ignored.

Help.Tip: Units to use for aperture parameter values.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_AP_UNITS
Units to use for aperture parameter values.
 
 Default = GRID
 Allowed = DIST  (Use feet or meters.)
 Allowed = GRID  (Use grid units (header word 7 and 8 units).)
 Allowed = ANG   (Use angle in degrees.)
 The value of OPT_AP_UNITS determines which arrays of the aperture parameters
 linked arrays are active.

Help.Tip: Maximum aperture in the X direction in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DIST_AP_X_MAX
Maximum aperture in the X direction in feet or meters.
 
 Default = GRID_AP_X_MAX * X_GRID_DIST
 Allowed = real >= 0

Help.Tip: Maximum aperture in the Y direction in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DIST_AP_Y_MAX
Maximum aperture in the Y direction in feet or meters.
 
 Default = GRID_AP_Y_MAX * Y_GRID_DIST
 Allowed = real >= 0

Help.Tip: Spacing within aperture and travel time table.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DIST_AP_X_INC
Spacing within aperture and travel time table.
 
 Default = -1 = 5. * X_INC
 Allowed = real
 For depth imaging this defines the maximum size of travel time tables.
 Increasing this increases memory linearly and CPU nonlinearly.
 The travel time table is computed and saved using a spacing of DIST_AP_X_INC
 between locations within the table. The larger DIST_AP_X_INC gets the less CPU
 time and memory is recquired at the cost of decreased accuracy.

Help.Tip: Y spacing within precomputed tables.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DIST_AP_Y_INC
Y spacing within precomputed tables.
 
 Default = -1 = 5 * Y_INC
 Allowed = real
 kdmig precomputes a number of tables on a coarse horizontal grid.
 DIST_AP_Y_INC defines the Y spacing within these tables.
 Needed values are computed from these tables via linear interpolation.
 Decreasing DIST_AP_Y_INC increases memory linearly and CPU nonlinearly.
 
 For depth migration:
 The travel time table is computed and saved using a spacing of AP_Y_INC
 between locations within the table. The larger AP_Y_INC gets the less CPU
 time and memory is recquired at the cost of decreased accuracy.

Help.Tip: Maximum aperture in the X direction in grid units.
Help.Text:
kdmig - GRID_AP_X_MAX
Maximum aperture in the X direction in grid units.
 
 Default = 100
 Allowed = real >= 0

Help.Tip: Maximum aperture in the Y direction in grid units.
Help.Text:
kdmig - GRID_AP_Y_MAX
Maximum aperture in the Y direction in grid units.
 
 Default = 100
 Allowed = real >= 0

Help.Tip: Spacing within aperture and travel time table.
Help.Text:
kdmig - GRID_AP_X_INC
Spacing within aperture and travel time table.
 
 Default = -1 = 5. * X_INC
 Allowed = real
 For depth imaging this defines the maximum size of travel time tables.
 Increasing this increases memory linearly and CPU nonlinearly.
 The travel time table is computed and saved using a spacing of GRID_AP_X_INC
 between locations within the table. The larger GRID_AP_X_INC gets the less CPU
 time and memory is recquired at the cost of decreased accuracy.

Help.Tip: Y spacing within precomputed tables.
Help.Text:
kdmig - GRID_AP_Y_INC
Y spacing within precomputed tables.
 
 Default = -1 = 5 * Y_INC
 Allowed = real
 kdmig precomputes a number of tables on a coarse horizontal grid.
 GRID_AP_Y_INC defines the Y spacing within these tables.
 Needed values are computed from these tables via linear interpolation.
 Decreasing GRID_AP_Y_INC increases memory linearly and CPU nonlinearly.

Help.Tip: Array of depths, in feet or meters, corresponding to AP_X values.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DEP_AP_X
Array of depths, in feet or meters, corresponding to AP_X values.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real  (linked array)
 Array of depths, in feet or meters, corresponding to values of half-aperture
 in the x direction.

Help.Tip: Array of values of half-aperture to use in x direction.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DIST_AP_X
Array of values of half-aperture to use in x direction.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0  (linked array)
 Array of depth dependent half-aperture values to use in the x direction, in
 feet or meters.  Actual values used will not exceed AP_MAX_X.

Help.Tip: Array of values of half-aperture to use in x direction.
Help.Text:
kdmig - GRID_AP_X
Array of values of half-aperture to use in x direction.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0  (linked array)
 Array of depth dependent half-aperture values to use in the x direction, in
 grid units.  Actual values used will not exceed AP_MAX_X.

Help.Tip: Array of values of half-aperture to use in x direction.
Help.Text:
kdmig - ANG_AP_X
Array of values of half-aperture to use in x direction.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0  (linked array)
 Array of depth dependent half-aperture values to use in the x direction, in
 degrees.  Actual values used will not exceed AP_MAX_X.

Help.Tip: Array of depths, in feet or meters, corresponding to AP_Y values.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DEP_AP_Y
Array of depths, in feet or meters, corresponding to AP_Y values.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real (linked array)
 Array of depths, in feet or meters, corresponding to values of half-aperture
 in the y direction.

Help.Tip: Array of values of half-aperture to use in y direction.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DIST_AP_Y
Array of values of half-aperture to use in y direction.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0  (linked array)
 Array of depth dependent half-aperture values to use in the y direction, in
 feet or meters.  Actual values used will not exceed AP_MAX_Y.

Help.Tip: Array of values of half-aperture to use in y direction.
Help.Text:
kdmig - GRID_AP_Y
Array of values of half-aperture to use in y direction.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0  (linked array)
 Array of depth dependent half-aperture values to use in the y direction, in
 grid units.  Actual values used will not exceed AP_MAX_Y.

Help.Tip: Array of values of half-aperture to use in y direction.
Help.Text:
kdmig - ANG_AP_Y
Array of values of half-aperture to use in y direction.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0  (linked array)
 Array of depth dependent half-aperture values to use in the y direction, in
 degrees.  Actual values used will not exceed AP_MAX_Y.

Help.Tip: Maximum offset in the X direction in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OFF_X_MAX
Maximum offset in the X direction in feet or meters.
 
 Default = (OFF_TOT-1)*OFF_INC+OFF_INIT+OFF_INC/2
 Allowed = real
 This affects the imaging aperture and the travel time table size.

Help.Tip: Maximum offset in the Y direction in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OFF_Y_MAX
Maximum offset in the Y direction in feet or meters.
 
 Default = (OFF_TOT-1)*OFF_INC+OFF_INIT+OFF_INC/2
 Allowed = real
 This affects the imaging aperture and the travel time table size.

Help.Tip: Array of maximum offsets corresponding to DEPTH_OFF values.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OFFSETS
Array of maximum offsets corresponding to DEPTH_OFF values.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0 (linked array)
 Array of values of maximum offset, in feet or meters, corresponding to
 DEPTH_OFF values.  DEPTH_OFF and OFFSETS constitute a depth-offset mute for
 KDMIG.

Help.Tip: Array of image trace depths, corresponding to OFFSETS values.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OFF_DEP
Array of image trace depths, corresponding to OFFSETS values.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real (linked array)
 Array of image trace depths, corresponding to maximum input trace offset
 values.  OFF_DEP and OFFSETS constitute a depth-offset mute for KDMIG.

Help.Tip: Isotropic or type of anisotropic method to use.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_ANISO
Isotropic or type of anisotropic method to use.
 
 Default = ISOTROPIC
 Allowed = ISOTROPIC   (Do not use an anisotropic method.)
 Allowed = ANISOTROPIC (Use vertical transverse isotropic (VTI) method.)
 Allowed = TILTED_BED  (Use tilted bed transverse isotropic method.)
 Active only if OPT_TABLE = EIKONAL.

Help.Tip: Whether to use velocity disk buffer.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_VBUF
Whether to use velocity disk buffer.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO  Do not use a disk buffer for the velocity.
 Allowed = YES Do     use a disk buffer for the velocity.

Help.Tip: Whether to write a vleocity trace file.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_VTRC
Whether to write a vleocity trace file.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO    Do not write a velocity trace file.
 Allowed = MODEL Write the velocity trace file using the model grid.
 Allowed = IMAGE Write the velocity trace file using the image grid.

Help.Tip: Root name for velocity disk buffer.
Help.Text:
kdmig - ROOT_VBUF
Root name for velocity disk buffer.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = CHAR

Help.Tip: Path name for model coefficient trace file.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PATH_VTRC
Path name for model coefficient trace file.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = CHAR

Help.Tip: Depth velocity gradient is measured from.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DEPTH_VEL_MIG
Depth velocity gradient is measured from.
 
 Default = 0.
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: Velocity gradient.
Help.Text:
kdmig - GRAD_VEL_MIG
Velocity gradient.
 
 Default = 0.
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: Whether to use constant velocity or velocity file.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_VEL
Whether to use constant velocity or velocity file.
 
 Default = CONSTANT
 Allowed = PATH
 Allowed = CONSTANT
 
 If OPT_VEL = CONSTANT, then constant velocity migration will be used,
 using the velocity entered for parameter CONST_VEL_MIG.
 
 If OPT_VEL = PATH, then define velocities by velocity file whose pathname
 is entered in PATH_VEL.

Help.Tip: Constant velocity used for migration.
Help.Text:
kdmig - CONST_VEL_MIG
Constant velocity used for migration.
 
 Default = 2000.
 Allowed = real > 0.
 If PATH_VEL = NONE, KDMIG will use a constant velocity equal to CONST_VEL_MIG.

Help.Tip: velocity path name.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SELECT_PATH_VEL
velocity path name.

Help.Tip: Pathname of velocity model file.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PATH_VEL
Pathname of velocity model file.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character
 Pathname of velocity model file.
 
 If OPT_ANISO = ANISOTROPIC or TILTED_BED, then KDMIG assumes this file
 contains the horizontal interval velocity.
 
 If PATH_VEL = NONE, KDMIG will use a constant velocity equal to CONST_VEL_MIG.

Help.Tip: Whether to use constant or spatialy varying eta.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_ETA
Whether to use constant or spatialy varying eta.
 
 Default = CONSTANT
 Allowed = PATH
 Allowed = CONSTANT
 
 If OPT_ETA = CONSTANT, then constant eta coefficient will be used,
 using the value entered for parameter CONST_ETA.
 
 If OPT_ETA = PATH, then define eta coefficients by file whose pathname
 is entered in PATH_ETA.

Help.Tip: Constant steep dip anisotropic parameter value.
Help.Text:
kdmig - CONST_ETA
Constant steep dip anisotropic parameter value.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real
 If PATH_ETA = NONE, the steep dip anisotropic coefficient is CONST_ETA.
 
 CONST_ETA = 0.0 for the isotropic case.

Help.Tip: eta path name.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SELECT_PATH_ETA
eta path name.

Help.Tip: Pathname of file containing steep dip anisotropic parameter.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PATH_ETA
Pathname of file containing steep dip anisotropic parameter.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character
 Pathname of file containing variable steep dip anisotropic parameter.
 
 If PATH_ETA = NONE, the steep dip anisotropic coefficient is CONST_ETA.

Help.Tip: Whether to use constant or spatialy varying vz.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_VZ
Whether to use constant or spatialy varying vz.
 
 Default = CONSTANT
 Allowed = PATH
 Allowed = CONSTANT
 
 If OPT_VZ = CONSTANT, use a constant VZ value of CONST_VZVX * velocity,
 using the value entered for parameter CONST_VZVX.
 
 If OPT_VZ = PATH, use a spatially varying VZ defined in a file whose
 path is entered in PATH_VZ.

Help.Tip: Constant vertical / horizontal velocity ratio.
Help.Text:
kdmig - CONST_VZVX
Constant vertical / horizontal velocity ratio.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.
 If PATH_VZ = NONE, the vertical velocity is CONST_VZVX times the horizontal
 velocity.  CONST_VZVX = 1.0 for the isotropic case.

Help.Tip: vz path name.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SELECT_PATH_VZ
vz path name.

Help.Tip: Pathname of vertical velocity model file for anisotropic migration.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PATH_VZ
Pathname of vertical velocity model file for anisotropic migration.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character
 Pathname of file containing variable vertical velocity model for anisotropic
 migration.
 
 If PATH_VZ = NONE, the vertical velocity is CONST_VZVX times the horizontal
 velocity.

Help.Tip: Whether to use constant or spatially varying X_SIN.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_X_SIN
Whether to use constant or spatially varying X_SIN.
 
 Default = CONSTANT
 Allowed = PATH
 Allowed = CONSTANT
 
 If OPT_X_SIN = CONSTANT, use a constant X_SIN value, specified by the
 CONST_X_SIN parameter.
 
 If OPT_X_SIN = PATH, use a spatially varying X_SIN from a file
 specified by PATH_X_SIN.
 
 The X_SIN coefficient is the sine of the anisotropic coefficient dip angle
 projected into the x,z plane.
 For a horizontal geometry x_sin = y_sin = 0.
 For a 30 degree dip from the horizontal in the x direction, x_sin = .5
 For a 45 degree dip from the horizontal in the x direction, x_sin = .7071
 The true dip of the anisotropic coefficient from the z axis is:
 asin ( sqrt ( 1. - x_sin**2 - y_sin**2 ) )

Help.Tip: Constant sin of dip angle in x-direction for the tilted bed option.
Help.Text:
kdmig - CONST_X_SIN
Constant sin of dip angle in x-direction for the tilted bed option.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real
 If PATH_X_SIN = NONE, the axis of symmetry for the tilted bed anisotropy
 will be defined by the CONST_X_SIN parameter.

Help.Tip: x_sin path name.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SELECT_PATH_X_SIN
x_sin path name.

Help.Tip: Pathname of file containing sin of dip angle in x-direction.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PATH_X_SIN
Pathname of file containing sin of dip angle in x-direction.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character
 Pathname of file containing variable sin of dip angle in x-direction for
 the tilted bed option.
 
 If PATH_X_SIN = NONE, the axis of symmetry for the tilted bed anisotropy
 will be defined by the CONST_X_SIN parameter.

Help.Tip: Whether to use constant or spatially varying Y_SIN.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_Y_SIN
Whether to use constant or spatially varying Y_SIN.
 
 Default = CONSTANT
 Allowed = PATH
 Allowed = CONSTANT
 
 If OPT_Y_SIN = CONSTANT, use a constant Y_SIN value, specified by the
 CONST_Y_SIN parameter.
 
 If OPT_Y_SIN = PATH, use a spatially varying Y_SIN from a file
 specified by PATH_Y_SIN.
 
 The Y_SIN coefficient is the sine of the anisotropic coefficient dip angle
 projected into the y,z plane.
 For a horizontal geometry x_sin = y_sin = 0.
 For a 30 degree dip from the horizontal in the y direction, y_sin = .5
 For a 45 degree dip from the horizontal in the y direction, y_sin = .7071
 The true dip of the anisotropic coefficient from the z axis is:
 asin ( sqrt ( 1. - x_sin**2 - y_sin**2 ) )

Help.Tip: Constant sin of dip angle in y-direction for the tilted bed option.
Help.Text:
kdmig - CONST_Y_SIN
Constant sin of dip angle in y-direction for the tilted bed option.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real
 If PATH_Y_SIN = NONE, the axis of symmetry for the tilted bed anisotropy
 will be defined by the CONST_Y_SIN parameter.

Help.Tip: y_sin path name.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SELECT_PATH_Y_SIN
y_sin path name.

Help.Tip: Pathname of file containing sin of dip angle in y-direction.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PATH_Y_SIN
Pathname of file containing sin of dip angle in y-direction.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character
 Pathname of file containing variable sin of dip angle in y-direction for
 the tilted bed option.
 
 If PATH_Y_SIN = NONE, the axis of symmetry for the tilted bed anisotropy
 will be defined by the CONST_Y_SIN parameter.

Help.Tip: Whether migration velocity analysis (FCTR_VEL array) is active.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_VA
Whether migration velocity analysis (FCTR_VEL array) is active.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES/NO
 If OPT_VA = YES, then the FCTR_VEL array is active for migration velocity
 analysis.  This function only operates when OPT_TABLE_OPERATION = IMAGE.
 
 If OPT_VA = NO, then the FCTR_VEL array is inactive.

Help.Tip: Array of velocity multipliers for migration velocity analysis.
Help.Text:
kdmig - FCTR_VEL
Array of velocity multipliers for migration velocity analysis.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0  (array)
 KDMIG produces a sequence of travel times by dividing the computed travel
 times by each of the elements of the FCTR_VEL array in turn.  (This is
 equivalent to multiplying the velocity by each of the elements of the
 FCTR_VEL array).  It then uses each of these travel times to produce an output
 image.  As many output images are created as the number of elements in the
 FCTR_VEL array.
 
 Output image traces are labeled in header word 24 with the index number of
 the FCTR_VEL array corresponding to that image (from 1 to the total number of
 multipliers) and in header word 63 with the corresponding velocity
 multiplier.

Help.Tip: Whether to use the converted wave velocity ratio V_SRC_REC.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_CONVERTED
Whether to use the converted wave velocity ratio V_SRC_REC.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES  - enable  converted wave velocity ratio V_SRC_REC.
 Allowed = NO   - disable converted wave velocity ratio V_SRC_REC.

Help.Tip: Ratio of source velocity to receiver velocity (Vs / Vr).
Help.Text:
kdmig - V_SRC_REC
Ratio of source velocity to receiver velocity (Vs / Vr).
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.
 Used for depth migrating p to s converted waves.
 This will adjust apertures, amplitude and aliasing for p to s converted waves.
 
 Active only if OPT_CONVERTED = YES.

Help.Tip: Button that displays memory and disk requirements when pressed.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DISPLAY_INFO
Button that displays memory and disk requirements when pressed.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = -
 Pressing the DISPLAY_INFO button causes memory and disk requirements to be
 calculated and displayed.

Help.Tip: Type of image node divison.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DIV_TYPE
Type of image node divison.
 
 Default = ROUND
 Allowed = ROUND for round robin distribution
 Allowed = BLOCK for block distribution
 Allowed = ZERO  to distrubte to pe 0 only.
 Allowed = ALL   to distrubte to all pes.
 
 DIV_TYPE defines the type of Y node division among pes
   0 = round robin, 1 = block, 2 = 0 only, 3 = all
 
   DIV_TYPE=ROUND, Round robin division
   means for a job with NY_MIG=100, Number of PES=4
   pe 0 gets Y nodes 1,5, 9,..., 97
   pe 1 gets Y nodes 2,6,10,..., 98
   pe 2 gets Y nodes 3,7,11,..., 99
   pe 3 gets Y nodes 4,8,12,...,100
 
   DIV_TYPE=BLOCK, Block division
   means for a job with NY_MIG=100, Number of PES=4
   pe 0 gets Y nodes  1- 25
   pe 1 gets Y nodes 26- 50
   pe 2 gets Y nodes 51- 75
   pe 3 gets Y nodes 76-100
 
   DIV_TYPE=ZERO, 0 only division
   means for a job with NY_MIG=100, Number of PES=4
   pe 0 gets Y nodes  1-100
   pe 1 gets Y nodes  0-  0
   pe 2 gets Y nodes  0-  0
   pe 3 gets Y nodes  0-  0
 
   DIV_TYPE=ALL, all division
   means for a job with NY_MIG=100, Number of PES=4
   pe 0 gets Y nodes  1-100
   pe 1 gets Y nodes  1-100
   pe 2 gets Y nodes  1-100
   pe 3 gets Y nodes  1-100

Help.Tip: Use ppio for trace io.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_USE_PPIO
Use ppio for trace io.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES use ppio routines.
 Allowed = NO use TRCIO routines.

Help.Tip: What method for interpolating output traces.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_MAP_APPLY
What method for interpolating output traces.
 
 Default = MAP_APPLY_I
 Allowed = MAP_APPLY_C Use MAP_APPLY_C   which does not include gradients.
 Allowed = MAP_APPLY_F Use MAP_APPLY_F   which does not include gradients.
 Allowed = MAP_APPLY_G Use MAP_APPLY_G   which does     include gradients.
 Allowed = MAP_APPLY_H Use MAP_APPLY_H   which includes gradients and paz.
 Allowed = MAP_APPLY_I Use MAP_APPLY_H_C which includes gradients and paz.
 KMIG will use MAP_APPLY_C when MIG_TYPE = DMO or OPT_OUTPUT .ne. IMAGE

Help.Tip: Number of cpus per parallel processing group.
Help.Text:
kdmig - CPUS_PER_GROUP
Number of cpus per parallel processing group.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = 1 <= int <= number pes in job
 kdmig will break the NUM_CPUS = number of pes in the job, processors
 into PAR_GROUPS groups of processors.
 Each group will have a maximum of CPUS_PER_GROUP proecessors in the job,
 and will image a subset of the input traces and construct
 an image indiependantly from th eother groups.  At the end
 of processing the separate images will be summed to gether
 by kdmig and the result output on all pes.
 It is strongly reccommended that you set the number of
 processors, NUM_CPUS, in a job be a multiple of CPUS_PER_GROUP,
 so each group will have the same number of processors.  It is
 also best that all processors in a job be the same speed.
 
 The maximum number of processors in any group is :
 m_pe_grp = ( NUM_CPUS + par_groups - 1 ) / par_groups
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_2 = par_groups * m_pe_grp - NUM_CPUS
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_1 = NUM_CPUS - n_pe_grp_2

Help.Tip: Number of parallel processing groups.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PAR_GROUPS
Number of parallel processing groups.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = 1 <= int <= number pes in job
 kdmig will break the NUM_CPUS = number of pes in the job, processors
 into PAR_GROUPS groups of processors.
 Each group will have a maximum of CPUS_PER_GROUP proecessors in the job,
 and will image a subset of the input traces and construct
 an image indiependantly from th eother groups.  At the end
 of processing the separate images will be summed to gether
 by kdmig and the result output on all pes.
 It is strongly reccommended that you set the number of
 processors, NUM_CPUS, in a job be a multiple of CPUS_PER_GROUP,
 so each group will have the same number of processors.  It is
 also best that all processors in a job be the same speed.
 
 The maximum number of processors in any group is :
 m_pe_grp = ( NUM_CPUS + par_groups - 1 ) / par_groups
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_2 = par_groups * m_pe_grp - NUM_CPUS
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_1 = NUM_CPUS - n_pe_grp_2

Help.Tip: Total number of cpus in job.
Help.Text:
kdmig - NUM_CPUS
Total number of cpus in job.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = 1 <= int <= number pes in job
 kdmig will break the NUM_CPUS = number of pes in the job, processors
 into PAR_GROUPS groups of processors.
 Each group will have a maximum of CPUS_PER_GROUP proecessors in the job,
 and will image a subset of the input traces and construct
 an image indiependantly from th eother groups.  At the end
 of processing the separate images will be summed to gether
 by kdmig and the result output on all pes.
 It is strongly reccommended that you set the number of
 processors, NUM_CPUS, in a job be a multiple of CPUS_PER_GROUP,
 so each group will have the same number of processors.  It is
 also best that all processors in a job be the same speed.
 
 The maximum number of processors in any group is :
 m_pe_grp = ( NUM_CPUS + par_groups - 1 ) / par_groups
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_2 = par_groups * m_pe_grp - NUM_CPUS
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_1 = NUM_CPUS - n_pe_grp_2

Help.Tip: What level of map print.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_MAP_PRINT
What level of map print.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = int>= 0
 Higher values of OPT_MAP_PRINT print the map values at more stages
 in the computation.
 opt_map_print .eq. -1 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 1 after ksum_map_compute.
 opt_map_print .eq. -2 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 2 after ksum_map_gradient.
 opt_map_print .eq. -3 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 3 after ksum_paz_interpolate.
 opt_map_print .eq. -4 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 4 after ksum_mute_turn.
 opt_map_print .eq. -5 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 5 after ksum_doppler_apply.
 opt_map_print .eq. -6 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 6 after ksum_map_apply.

Help.Tip: First x,y imag enode to print map for.
Help.Text:
kdmig - FIRST_MAP_PRINT
First x,y imag enode to print map for.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int>= 0
 Maps for x,y image node locations FIRST_MAP_PRINT to LAST_MAP_PRINT
 are printed.

Help.Tip: Last x,y imag enode to print map for.
Help.Text:
kdmig - LAST_MAP_PRINT
Last x,y imag enode to print map for.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int>= 0
 Maps for x,y image node locations FIRST_MAP_PRINT to LAST_MAP_PRINT
 are printed.

Help.Tip: Maximum number of anti-alias filters to use.
Help.Text:
kdmig - NUM_AA
Maximum number of anti-alias filters to use.
 
 Default = 31
 Allowed = int > 0
 KDMIG uses the Claerbout integration method for anti-aliasing which makes a
 number of copies of the input trace, each with a different anti-alias filter
 applied.
 
 NUM_AA = 31 is usually sufficient, NUM_AA = 40 is probably excessive.

Help.Tip: Effective input trace physical spacing, in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DIST_AA
Effective input trace physical spacing, in feet or meters.
 
 Default = compute default from transformation grid
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 The effective input trace physical spacing, in feet or meters, for use in
 calculating the anti-alias filter.  It should be roughly the average of
 the X and the Y spacing of input traces.  Larger distances
 produce more severe anti-aliasing, so using the larger of the X or the
 Y output trace spacing is the most conservative approach.

Help.Tip: Antialias normalization.
Help.Text:
kdmig - NORM_AA
Antialias normalization.
 
 Default = MAX_AMP
 Allowed = MAX_AMP Preserve maximum ampplitude.
 Allowed = NONE    No antialias nrmaliazation.

Help.Tip: Type of amplitude treatment.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_AMPLITUDE
Type of amplitude treatment.
 
 Default = HPHILLIPS
 Allowed = HCONOCO
 Allowed = VOFZ
 Allowed = USER
 To get the heritage Conoco   ampltiude scaling use OPT_AMPLITUDE = HCONOCO
 To get the heritage Phillips ampltiude scaling use OPT_AMPLITUDE = HPHILLIPS
 To get a vofz raytraced      ampltiude scaling use OPT_AMPLITUDE = VOFZ
 To get some other            amplitude scaling use OPT_AMPLITUDE = USER
 OPT_AMPLITUDE = VOFZ_3D applies a 2D v(z) amplitude correction and sets
 OPT_AMP_COSINE = VOFZ_2D, PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = +0., PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = -0.
 OPT_AMPLITUDE = VOFZ_2D applies a 3D v(z) amplitude correction and sets
 OPT_AMP_COSINE = VOFZ_2D, PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = +0., PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = -0.
 OPT_AMPLITUDE = VOFZ_2.5d applies a 2.5d v(z) amplitude correction and sets
 OPT_AMP_COSINE = VOFZ_2.5D, PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = +0., PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = -0.
 OPT_AMPLITUDE  = HCONOCO sets
 OPT_AMP_COSINE = HCONOCO,   PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = +0., PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = -0.
 OPT_AMPLITUDE  = HPHILLIPS sets
 OPT_AMP_COSINE = HPHILLIPS, PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = +1., PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = -1.
 OPT_AMPLITUDE  = USER allows an arbitray combination of parameters.
 OPT_AMP_COSINE, PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP, PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT
 The v(z) amplitude scaling computes a v(z) curved ray amplitude correction
 This assumes no divergence correction has been applied to the input data
 prior to input to imaging.
 Heritage Conoco's ampltiude scaling was cos(dip)
 this assumes a divergence correction has been applied to the input data
 prior to input to imaging and zero offset.
 Heritage Philip's ampltiude scaling was
 ( time / depth ) * cos(source)**2+cos(reciever)**2)
 this assumes no divergence correction has been applied to the input data
 prior to input to imaging.

Help.Tip: Type of cosine dip samplitude scaling.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_AMP_COSINE
Type of cosine dip samplitude scaling.
 
 Default = HCONOCO
 Allowed = HPHILLIPS
 Allowed = VOFZ_2D
 Allowed = VOFZ_2.5D
 Allowed = VOFZ_3D

Help.Tip: Scale input data by (TIME-MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP
Scale input data by (TIME-MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Apply an amplitude scaling of (TIME - MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP) ** PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP
 to each input trace before imaging.
 Using PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = 0. yields no amplitude scaling before imaging.

Help.Tip: Scale input data by (TIME-MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP.
Help.Text:
kdmig - MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP
Scale input data by (TIME-MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Apply an amplitude scaling of (TIME - MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP) ** PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP
 to each input trace before imaging.
 Using PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = 0. yields no amplitude scaling before imaging.

Help.Tip: Scale output data by (DEPTH-MIN_AMP_SCALE_OUT)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT
Scale output data by (DEPTH-MIN_AMP_SCALE_OUT)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Apply an amplitude scaling of (DEPTH - MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP) ** PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT
 to each output trace after imaging.
 Using PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = 0. yields no amplitude scaling after imaging.
 For time migration DEPTH will be output time.

Help.Tip: Scale output data by (DEPTH-MIN_AMP_SCALE_OUT)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT.
Help.Text:
kdmig - MIN_AMP_SCALE_OUT
Scale output data by (DEPTH-MIN_AMP_SCALE_OUT)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Apply an amplitude scaling of (DEPTH - MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP) ** PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT
 to each output trace after imaging.
 Using PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = 0. yields no amplitude scaling after imaging.
 For time migration DEPTH will be output time.

Help.Tip: Power for (frequency ** PWR_FILT) filter applied to input.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PWR_FILT
Power for (frequency ** PWR_FILT) filter applied to input.
 
 Default = 0.5 for 2D, 1.0 for 3D
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 Theoretical values are PWR_FILT = 0.5 for 2D migration and PWR_FILT = 1.0 for
 3D migration.  (But migrating a single line from a 3D survey to a single
 output line is really 2D so in that case PWR_FILT should be 0.5.)
 
 Lower values of PWR_FILT emphasize low frequencies, higher values of PWR_FILT
 emphasize high frequencies.  Adjusting the PWR_FILT value allows you to
 adjust the image frequency balance and the apparent amount of noise in the
 image.  This may be desirable for some datasets.
 Note, the PWR_FILT in the hybrid system is defined differently:
 PWR_FILT = 1 for 2D; PWR_FILT = 2 for 3D.

Help.Tip: Phase shift, in degrees, to apply to the input traces.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PHASE_FILT
Phase shift, in degrees, to apply to the input traces.
 
 Default = 45 for 2D, 90 for 3D
 Allowed = 45 or 90
 Theoretically correct values are PHASE_FILT = 45 for 2D migration and
 PHASE_FILT = 90 for 3D migration.  (But migrating a single line from a 3D
 survey to a single output line is really 2D so in that case PHASE_FILT should
 be 45.)

Help.Tip: Number of input traces between migration status prints.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PRINT_INC
Number of input traces between migration status prints.
 
 Default = 1000
 Allowed = int > 0
 KDMIG writes informational text on CPU time and elapsed time and location of
 input and output traces for the first few input traces and again after every
 additional PRINT_INC input traces.
 
 PRINT_INC = 0 disables migration status prints.

Help.Tip: Whether memory allocation details will be printed in .rpt file?
Help.Text:
kdmig - PRINT_MEMORY
Whether memory allocation details will be printed in .rpt file?
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES/NO

Help.Tip: Print debug information.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PRINT_DEBUG
Print debug information.
 
 Default = BRIEF
 Allowed = NONE     - no debug information is printed.
 Allowed = BRIEF    - default debug information is printed.
 Allowed = DETAILED - detailed debug information is printed.
 Allowed = DEBUG    - full debug information is printed.

Help.Tip: Whether stack scaling is used.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_FOS_SCALE
Whether stack scaling is used.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES/NO
 If OPT_FOS_SCALE = YES, then stack scaling is used.
 
 If OPT_FOS_SCALE = NO, then stack scaling is not used and fold of stack
 sampling is disabled.

Help.Tip: Fold of Stack Exponential for stack scaling.
Help.Text:
kdmig - FOS_PWR
Fold of Stack Exponential for stack scaling.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = 1.0 >= FOS_PWR >= 0.0
 Perform stack scaling of output trace sample values by dividing the
 composited trace sample value by the local fold raised to the FOS_PWR power.

Help.Tip: First depth for sampling fold of stack, in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
kdmig - FOS_DEP_INIT
First depth for sampling fold of stack, in feet or meters.
 
 Default = DEP_INIT
 Allowed = real >= DEP_INIT

Help.Tip: Increment between depths to sample fold of stack, in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
kdmig - FOS_DEP_INC
Increment between depths to sample fold of stack, in feet or meters.
 
 Default = DEP_INC
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Last depth for sampling fold of stack, in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
kdmig - FOS_DEP_LAST
Last depth for sampling fold of stack, in feet or meters.
 
 Default = DEP_LAST
 Allowed = real >= DEP_INIT

Help.Tip: Number of depths for sampling fold of stack.
Help.Text:
kdmig - FOS_DEP_TOT
Number of depths for sampling fold of stack.
 
 Default = DEP_TOT
 Allowed = int > 0

Help.Tip: Whether a stretch mute (Doppler mute) is used.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_DOPP
Whether a stretch mute (Doppler mute) is used.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES/NO
 If OPT_DOPP = YES, then use a stretch mute.
 
 If OPT_DOPP = NO, then do not use a stretch mute.

Help.Tip: Doppler mute (stretch mute) parameter.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DOPPLER
Doppler mute (stretch mute) parameter.
 
 Default = 3.0
 Allowed = real > 1.0
 Portions of the migration operator that would produce a time stretch factor
 greater than DOPPLER are muted off.  For this calculation output depth is
 converted approximately to time by:
 
     output_time = 2 * output_depth/average_velocity,
 
 where the average_velocity is averaged laterally over the image volume for
 each depth value.
 
 Larger values of DOPPLER correspond to less severe muting.  Very large values
 may introduce low frequency artifacts.  Smaller values of DOPPLER may
 eliminate steep dips.

Help.Tip: Mute events whose input time decreases with output time or depth.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_MUTE_TURN
Mute events whose input time decreases with output time or depth.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES, NO
 If OPT_MUTE_TURN = NO,  then allow any input time to output relation ship.
 If OPT_MUTE_TURN = YES, then mute when input time decreases
                         with output time or depth.

Help.Tip: Kirchhoff summation taper length, in depth units.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DEP_TAPER
Kirchhoff summation taper length, in depth units.
 
 Default = 15 * DEP_INC
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Image sum lateral taper distance in distance units.
Help.Text:
kdmig - XY_TAPER
Image sum lateral taper distance in distance units.
 
 Default = 0.
 Allowed = real >= 0

Border.title: Travel time table file name definition

Help.Tip: Travel time table operation to perform.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_TABLE_OPERATION
Travel time table operation to perform.
 
 Default = ALL
 Allowed = INITIALIZE (Initialize travel time table space.)
 Allowed = COMPUTE    (Compute travel time tables.)
 Allowed = IMAGE      (Perform imaging.)
 Allowed = ALL        (Initialize, compute and image in one job.)
 Allowed = CHECK      (Check on travel time table integrity.)
 Allowed = USER       (Enable individual operation buttons.)
 Most travel time table parameters are active only if
 OPT_TABLE_OPERATION = ZERO or ALL.

Help.Tip: Travel time calculation method.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TYPE_TABLE_CALC
Travel time calculation method.
 
 Default = EIKONAL
 Allowed = EIKONAL  - Eikonal method.  2D and 3D isotropic.
 Allowed = EIKONALA - Eikonal method.  2D and 3D anisotropic.
 Allowed = EIKONGRP - Eikonal method.  2D and 3D anisotropic using
                      analytical group velocity.
 Allowed = RAYTRACE - Raytracing, 2D and 3D.
 Allowed = RAYTRVTI - Raytracing, 2D and 3D VTI.
 Allowed = VOFZ     - V(Z) raytraceing, 2D and 3D.
 Allowed = STRAIGHT - Straight rays, 2D and 3D.
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 If KMIG ever has an error during creating a travel time table
 it will stop migrating traces and flush out the remaining
 partialy completed image traces.

Help.Tip: Whether to initialize travel time table space.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_INITIALIZE
Whether to initialize travel time table space.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES, initialize travel time table space.
 Allowed = NO,  then do not initialize travel time table space.
 Active only if OPT_TABLE_OPERATION = USER.

Help.Tip: Whether to compute travel time table space .
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_COMPUTE
Whether to compute travel time table space .
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES, compute travel time table space.
 Allowed = ALL, compute ALL travel time table space.
 Allowed = NO,  then do not compute travel time table space.
 Active only if OPT_TABLE_OPERATION = USER.
 If TABLE_COMPUTE = ALL KMIG will operate on all tables.
 This overrides the FIRST_TABLE and LAST_TABLE parameters
 and sets them to 1 and the total number of tables respectively.

Help.Tip: Whether image is performed.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_IMAGE
Whether image is performed.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES, compute image.
 Allowed = NO,  then do not compute image.
 Active only if OPT_TABLE_OPERATION = USER.

Help.Tip: Test tables before computing.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_TEST
Test tables before computing.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES, Test tables and only compute if bad.
 Allowed = NO,  Do not test tables, compute all tables.
 
 TABLE_COMPUTE must be YES or ALL for TABLE_TEST to have any effect.
 
 If TABLE_TEST=YES, KDMIG and KMIG will test each travel time table between
 FIRST_TABLE to LAST_TABLE before computing it.  If the table does not pass
 the check process it will be recomputed.  If it does pass the check process
 it will not be recomputed.
 
 Note during the check process KTABLE looks at each tables label section
 for information on the table location.
 If this is correct, placed there when the table is first computed,
 the check process is passed.
 If it is not correct the check process is failed.
 This can be due to changing table characteristics such as size,
 a bad disk or if the table has never been computed.

Help.Tip: Whether to check on travel time table integrity.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_CHECK
Whether to check on travel time table integrity.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES, perform travel time table check.
 Allowed = NO,  then do not perform travel time table check.
 Active only if OPT_TABLE_OPERATION = USER.

Help.Tip: Maximum increment for eikonal calculations, in distance units.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_COMP_INC
Maximum increment for eikonal calculations, in distance units.
 
 Default = -1 = compute
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 If parameter TYPE_TABLE_CALC is set to EIKONAL, EIKONALA, or
 EIKONGRP, then TABLE_COMP_INC determines the maximum increment
 used between successive computational points in the travel time
 calculation step. The default value of -1 causes this distance
 to be computed.

Help.Tip: Number of travel time table datums.
Help.Text:
kdmig - NUM_DATUMS
Number of travel time table datums.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = 1, 2
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 For infomration only.  Thes user can not modify this.
 NUM_TABLES = NUM_DATUMS * TABLES_PER_DATUM

Help.Tip: Total number of travel time table.
Help.Text:
kdmig - NUM_TABLES
Total number of travel time table.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int >= 1
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 For infomration only.  Thes user can not modify this.
 NUM_TABLES = NUM_DATUMS * TABLES_PER_DATUM

Help.Tip: Total number of travel time tables for a single datum level.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLES_PER_DATUM
Total number of travel time tables for a single datum level.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int >= 1
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 For infomration only.  Thes user can not modify this.
 NUM_TABLES = NUM_DATUMS * TABLES_PER_DATUM

Help.Tip: First travel time table to compute in this job.
Help.Text:
kdmig - FIRST_TABLE
First travel time table to compute in this job.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int >= 1
 FIRST_TABLE and LAST_TABLE parameters are relevant only if
 OPT_TABLE_OPERATION = COMPUTE.

Help.Tip: Last travel time table to compute in this job.
Help.Text:
kdmig - LAST_TABLE
Last travel time table to compute in this job.
 
 Default = 999999999
 Allowed = int >= 0
 FIRST_TABLE and LAST_TABLE parameters are relevant only if
 OPT_TABLE_OPERATION = COMPUTE.

Help.Tip: Use the nearest travel time table?
Help.Text:
kdmig - NEAREST_TABLE
Use the nearest travel time table?
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES/NO
 If NEAREST_TABLE = NO, then KDMIG will abort if a needed travel time table
 falls outside the range defined in the travel time table file.
 
 If NEAREST_TABLE = YES, KDMIG will use the nearest travel time table in the
 file.

Help.Tip: Maximum travel time table size in gigabytes.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_SIZE
Maximum travel time table size in gigabytes.
 
 Default = 2.0
 Allowed = real > 0.
 The actual number of files used will depend upon this value and the total
 size of all the travel time tables.  On 32 bit machines the max file size is
 2.0 Gigabytes.
 
 The actual file names will be PATH_TABLE with a number appended to the end.

Help.Tip: Travel time table shape, NORMAL, and CUBE are valid.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_SHAPE
Travel time table shape, NORMAL, and CUBE are valid.
 
 Default = NORMAL
 Allowed = NORMAL gives a memory and disk efficent, complicated table shape.
 Allowed = CUBE yields a simple rectangular grid.

Help.Tip: Apply static correction to travel times during interpolation?
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_STATIC
Apply static correction to travel times during interpolation?
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES/NO

Help.Tip: Number of parameters to compute and store in travel time tables.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_PARMS
Number of parameters to compute and store in travel time tables.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = 1 = Travel times only.
 Allowed = 2 = Travel times and amplitudes.
 Allowed = 3 = Travel times, amplitudes and phases.
 
 Currently, only option TABLE_PARMS is implemented.

Help.Tip: Ordering of travel time tables on disk.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_ORDER
Ordering of travel time tables on disk.
 
 Default = ROUND_ROBIN
 Allowed = ROUND_ROBIN
 Allowed = BLOCK

Help.Tip: Travel time interpolation, before or during imaging.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_INTERPOLATE
Travel time interpolation, before or during imaging.
 
 Default = LOCAL
 Allowed = LOCAL  Interpolate those table nodes which are required.
 Allowed = GLOBAL Interpolate all table nodes .

Help.Tip: Number of bits to save for each travel time value on disk.
Help.Text:
kdmig - DISK_PACK
Number of bits to save for each travel time value on disk.
 
 Default = 32
 Allowed = 1 <= int <= 32
 Number of bits to save for each travel time value on disk.
 Using DISK_PACK = 1 uses the native word length.
 For production work use MEMORY_PACK = DISK_PACK.

Help.Tip: Number of bits to save for each travel time value in memory.
Help.Text:
kdmig - MEMORY_PACK
Number of bits to save for each travel time value in memory.
 
 Default = 32
 Allowed = 1 <= int <= 32
 Using MEMORY_PACK = 1 uses the native word length.
 For production work use MEMORY_PACK = DISK_PACK.

Help.Tip: Spherical interpolation scale factor.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SPHERICAL_SCALE
Spherical interpolation scale factor.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 For depth migration KDMIG will interpolate the coarse grid travel times
 from the source and receiver travel times.  If the distance to the top of
 the coarse grid to the source or receiver is less than TERP_DISTANCE
 KDMIG will compute the travel times by first computing the average slowness
 from the source or receiver to each table grid node and then use that
 average slowness to compute the travel time to the coarse grid nodes.
 TERP_DISTANCE is the distance at which the difference between linearly and
 spherically interpolated travel times using an average velocity model is less
 than DT * SPHERICAL_SCALE.

Help.Tip: Write ray QC files.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_TAB_QC
Write ray QC files.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO   Do not write ray QC files.
 Allowed = YES  Write ray QC files for the travel time tables
                between FIRST_TAB_QC and LAST_TAB_QC.
 
 If OPT_TAB_QC = YES KMIG will write a number of QC files for the
 first travel time table computed via raytraceing on the root pe.
 
 These QC files will begin a suffix defined by parameter ROOT_TAB_QC with
 a varyiable suffix which changes with the qc coefficient.
 Coeffiecients are only output if they are used during a compuation.
 Hence anisotropic ocefficients ar enot output for isotropic computations
 and the amplitude is output only when the amplitude
 is used as a ray slection criteria.
 
 xxxxx will be the travel time table index.
 
 The following QC files will all have the spatial grid characteristics
 of the first travel time table computed by the root pe.
 
 xxxxx_unf.trc - travel time field before undfined values have been filled in.
 xxxxx_tim.trc - travel time field after  undfined values have been filled in.
 xxxxx_amp.trc - amplitude field
 xxxxx_phs.trc - phase field - currently never computed
 xxxxx_vxt.trc - min max velocity field used when
 xxxxx_rst.trc - ray path length
 xxxxx_dtt.trc - ray trace time step increment.
 
 The following QC files will all have the spatial grid characteristics
 of the velocity field for first travel time table computed by the root pe.
 
 xxxxx_vxv.trc - horizontal velocity field
 xxxxx_vev.trc - eta coefficient field
 xxxxx_vzv.trc - vertical velocity field
 xxxxx_sxv.trc - x dip field
 xxxxx_syv.trc - y dip field
 xxxxx_dtv.trc - ray trace time step increment.
 
 
 The following QC files will all have the spatial grid characteristics
 the first travel time table  and will be output if tables are packed
 
 xxxxx_pack_o  - original      travel times before packing
 xxxxx_pack_r  - reconstructed travel times after unpacking
 xxxxx_pack_d  - difference between original and reconstructed travel times

Help.Tip: First travel time table to output qc files for in this job.
Help.Text:
kdmig - FIRST_TAB_QC
First travel time table to output qc files for in this job.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int >= 1

Help.Tip: Last travel time table to output qc files for in this job.
Help.Text:
kdmig - LAST_TAB_QC
Last travel time table to output qc files for in this job.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int >= 0

Help.Tip: Pathname for for file containing ray information.
Help.Text:
kdmig - ROOT_TAB_QC
Pathname for for file containing ray information.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character
 If ROOT_TAB_QC = NONE, no file is created.

Help.Tip: Whether to use TABLES_IN_MEMORY or TABLE_MEM_TO_USE.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_TABLE_MEM
Whether to use TABLES_IN_MEMORY or TABLE_MEM_TO_USE.
 
 Default = TABLES_IN_MEMORY
 Allowed = TABLES_IN_MEMORY, use TABLES_IN_MEMORY to compute TABLE_MEM_TO_USE.
 Allowed = TABLE_MEM_TO_USE, then use TABLE_MEM_TO_USE to compute
           TABLES_IN_MEMORY.

Help.Tip: Whether to use TABLES_ON_DISK or TABLE_DISK_TO_USE.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_TABLE_DISK
Whether to use TABLES_ON_DISK or TABLE_DISK_TO_USE.
 
 Default = TABLES_ON_DISK
 Allowed = TABLES_ON_DISK, use TABLES_ON_DISK to compute TABLE_DISK_TO_USE.
 Allowed = TABLE_DISK_TO_USE, then use TABLE_DISK_TO_USE to compute
           TABLES_ON_DISK.

Help.Tip: Maximum number of travel time tables saved in memory.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLES_IN_MEMORY
Maximum number of travel time tables saved in memory.
 
 Default = 8
 Allowed = int>= 1
 Increasing TABLES_IN_MEMORY decreases the amount of disk i/o  at the expense
 of increased memory usage.  The minimum values for TABLES_IN_MEMORY are
   TABLES_IN_MEMORY = 1 for TABLE_TYPE=VOFZ
   TABLES_IN_MEMORY >=2 for 2D poststack
   TABLES_IN_MEMORY >=4 for 2D prestack
   TABLES_IN_MEMORY >=4 for 3D poststack
   TABLES_IN_MEMORY >=8 for 3D prestack

Help.Tip: Maximum number of travel time tables saved on local disk.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLES_ON_DISK
Maximum number of travel time tables saved on local disk.
 
 Default = 100
 Allowed = int>= 0

Help.Tip: Amount of memory, in mbytes, to use for storing travel time tables.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_MEM_TO_USE
Amount of memory, in mbytes, to use for storing travel time tables.
 
 Default = 110.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Amount of disk, in gbytes, to use for storing travel time tables.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_DISK_TO_USE
Amount of disk, in gbytes, to use for storing travel time tables.
 
 Default = 2.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Packing level of travel time tables on local disk.
Help.Text:
kdmig - LOCAL_PACK
Packing level of travel time tables on local disk.
 
 Default = DISK
 Allowed = DISK   Tables are packed at the same level as on premanent disk.
 Allowed = MEMORY Tables are packed at the same level as in memory.

Help.Tip: Whether to input or compute default aperture depth parameters.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_AP_DEP
Whether to input or compute default aperture depth parameters.
 
 Default = USER
 Allowed = CALC, compute default aperture depth parameters.
 If OPT_AP_DEP = CALC KMIG computes the aperture depth parameters.

Help.Tip: Whether to input or compute default traveltime table parameters.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_TABLE_X
Whether to input or compute default traveltime table parameters.
 
 Default = USER
 Allowed = CALC, compute default travel time table spacing.
 If OPT_TABLE_X = CALC, KMIG computes the default traveltime table
 parameters in the X direction..

Help.Tip: Whether to input or compute default traveltime table parameters.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_TABLE_Y
Whether to input or compute default traveltime table parameters.
 
 Default = USER
 Allowed = CALC, compute default travel time table spacing.
 If OPT_TABLE_Y = CALC, KMIG computes the default traveltime table
 parameters in the Y direction.

Help.Tip: Minimum depth in travel time table.
Help.Text:
kdmig - AP_DEP_INIT
Minimum depth in travel time table.
 
 Default = compute
 Allowed = real
 Each individual travel time table contains travel time values calculated and
 saved at specific depth values specified by AP_DEP_INIT, AP_DEP_INC,
 AP_DEP_LAST and AP_DEP_TOT.

Help.Tip: First X location for travel time tables in HDR_X units.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_X_INIT
First X location for travel time tables in HDR_X units.
 
 Default = compute
 Allowed = real
 Travel time tables are computed and saved on a coarse grid with spacing
 TABLE_X_INC between X locations.  The travel times actually used are
 interpolated from the four surrounding tables computed on the coarse grid.
 The larger TABLE_X_INC gets the less CPU time and disk space is required at
 the cost of decreased accuracy.

Help.Tip: Minimum Y location for travel time tables in HDR_Y units.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_Y_INIT
Minimum Y location for travel time tables in HDR_Y units.
 
 Default = compute
 Allowed = real
 Travel time tables are computed and saved on a coarse grid with spacing
 TABLE_Y_INC between Y locations.  The travel times actually used are
 interpolated from the four surrounding tables computed on the coarse grid.
 The larger TABLE_Y_INC gets the less CPU time and disk space is required at
 the cost of decreased accuracy.

Help.Tip: Depth spacing within precomputed tables.
Help.Text:
kdmig - AP_DEP_INC
Depth spacing within precomputed tables.
 
 Default = compute
 Allowed = real
 Each individual travel time table contains travel time values calculated and
 saved at specific depth values specified by AP_DEP_INIT, AP_DEP_INC,
 AP_DEP_LAST and AP_DEP_TOT.

Help.Tip: X spacing between travel time tables in HDR_X units.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_X_INC
X spacing between travel time tables in HDR_X units.
 
 Default = compute
 Allowed = real
 Travel time tables are computed and saved on a coarse grid with spacing
 TABLE_X_INC between X locations.  The travel times actually used are
 interpolated from the four surrounding tables computed on the coarse grid.
 The larger TABLE_X_INC gets the less CPU time and disk space is required at
 the cost of decreased accuracy.

Help.Tip: Y spacing between travel time table in HDR_Y units.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_Y_INC
Y spacing between travel time table in HDR_Y units.
 
 Default = compute
 Allowed = real
 Travel time tables are computed and saved on a coarse grid with spacing
 TABLE_Y_INC between Y locations.  The travel times actually used are
 interpolated from the four surrounding tables computed on the coarse grid.
 The larger TABLE_Y_INC gets the less CPU time and disk space is required at
 the cost of decreased accuracy.

Help.Tip: Maximum depth in travel time table.
Help.Text:
kdmig - AP_DEP_LAST
Maximum depth in travel time table.
 
 Default = compute
 Allowed = real
 Each individual travel time table contains travel time values calculated and
 saved at specific depth values specified by AP_DEP_INIT, AP_DEP_INC,
 AP_DEP_LAST and AP_DEP_TOT.

Help.Tip: Last X location for travel time tables in HDR_X units.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_X_LAST
Last X location for travel time tables in HDR_X units.
 
 Default = compute
 Allowed = real
 Travel time tables are computed and saved on a coarse grid with spacing
 TABLE_X_INC between X locations.  The travel times actually used are
 interpolated from the four surrounding tables computed on the coarse grid.
 The larger TABLE_X_INC gets the less CPU time and disk space is required at
 the cost of decreased accuracy.

Help.Tip: Maximum Y location for travel time tables in HDR_Y units.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_Y_LAST
Maximum Y location for travel time tables in HDR_Y units.
 
 Default = compute
 Allowed = real
 Travel time tables are computed and saved on a coarse grid with spacing
 TABLE_Y_INC between Y locations.  The travel times actually used are
 interpolated from the four surrounding tables computed on the coarse grid.
 The larger TABLE_Y_INC gets the less CPU time and disk space is required at
 the cost of decreased accuracy.

Help.Tip: Number of depth locations in a travel time table.
Help.Text:
kdmig - AP_DEP_TOT
Number of depth locations in a travel time table.
 
 Default = compute from image range
 Allowed =  int>= 0
 Each individual travel time table contains travel time values calculated and
 saved at specific depth values specified by AP_DEP_INIT, AP_DEP_INC,
 AP_DEP_LAST and AP_DEP_TOT.

Help.Tip: Number of travel time tables in the X direction.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_X_TOT
Number of travel time tables in the X direction.
 
 Default = compute
 Allowed = int >= 0
 Travel time tables are computed and saved on a coarse grid with spacing
 TABLE_X_INC between X locations.  The travel times actually used are
 interpolated from the four surrounding tables computed on the coarse grid.
 The larger TABLE_X_INC gets the less CPU time and disk space is required at
 the cost of decreased accuracy.

Help.Tip: Number of travel time tables in the Y direction.
Help.Text:
kdmig - TABLE_Y_TOT
Number of travel time tables in the Y direction.
 
 Default = compute
 Allowed = int >= 0
 Travel time tables are computed and saved on a coarse grid with spacing
 TABLE_Y_INC between Y locations.  The travel times actually used are
 interpolated from the four surrounding tables computed on the coarse grid.
 The larger TABLE_Y_INC gets the less CPU time and disk space is required at
 the cost of decreased accuracy.

Help.Tip: Method to use for creating travel time table pathnames.
Help.Text:
kdmig - FILENAME_OPERATION
Method to use for creating travel time table pathnames.
 
 Default = PATH_1
 Allowed = PATH_1  (Create travel time table pathnames)
 Allowed = PATH_2  (Create travel time table pathnames)
 Allowed = PATH_3  (Create travel time table pathnames)
 Allowed = PATH_4  (Create travel time table pathnames)
 Allowed = PATH_5  (Create travel time table pathnames)
 Allowed = PATH_6  (Create travel time table pathnames)
 Allowed = CLEAR   (Clear the entries in PATH_TABLE.)
 Allowed = USER    (Allow manual entry in PATH_TABLE.)
 If FILENAME_OPERATION = FILE1, then 12 travel time table pathnames are
 created:  /ptmp/poeplx06/scratch/ through /ptmp/poeplx50/scratch/
 incrementing by 4 with the ROOT_TABLE value appended to each pathname.
 
 If FILENAME_OPERATION = FILE2, then 12 travel time table pathnames are
 created:  /ptmp/poeplx08/scratch/ through /ptmp/poeplx52/scratch/
 incrementing by 4 with the ROOT_TABLE value appended to each pathname.
 
 If FILENAME_OPERATION = CLEAR, then clear the entries in PATH_TABLE.
 
 If FILENAME_OPERATION = USER, then allow manual entry in PATH_TABLE.

Help.Tip: Root name for automatic travel time table pathname creation.
Help.Text:
kdmig - ROOT_TABLE
Root name for automatic travel time table pathname creation.
 
 Default = kdmig.table
 Allowed = character
 Pressing the PATH_1 button generates 12 travel time table pathnames:
 /ptmp/poeplx06/scratch/ through /ptmp/poeplx50/scratch/ incrementing by 4 with
 the ROOT_TABLE value appended to each pathname.
 
 Pressing the PATH_2 button generates 12 travel time table pathnames:
 /ptmp/poeplx08/scratch/ through /ptmp/poeplx52/scratch/ incrementing by 4 with
 the ROOT_TABLE value appended to each pathname.

Help.Tip: Array of pathnames for travel time table files.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PATH_TABLE
Array of pathnames for travel time table files.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = character
 Travel time table pathnames may be created automatically by pressing the
 PATH_1 or PATH_2 button.  These pathnames may then be edited if desired.  Or
 the pathnames may be entered manually.
 
 If the pathname starts with a valid directory such as /tmp/ptmp/hanson
 the file is written to that directory and becomes a permanent file, otherwise
 the file is temporary and is not saved after the job.
 
 If this file does not exist KDMIG will create it and write tables to it.
 If this file already exists KDMIG will use the tables already in the file.
 If this file already exists make sure that it was created using the same
 model file name and travel time table setup parameters.
 
 Tables are written to the various files in a round robin fashion.

Border.title: Travel time table file datum definition

Help.Tip: Whether datum statics are used.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_DATUM
Whether datum statics are used.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES/NO
 If OPT_DATUM = YES, then use datum statics.
 
 If OPT_DATUM = NO, then do not use datum statics.

Help.Tip: Whether to use constant source datum or datum file.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_SRC_DATUM
Whether to use constant source datum or datum file.
 
 Default = CONSTANT
 Allowed = PATH
 Allowed = CONSTANT
 
 If OPT_SRC_DATUM = CONSTANT, then the constant source datum specified
 by parameter CONST_SRC_DATUM will be used.
 
 If OPT_SRC_DATUM = PATH, then define source datum by file
 whose pathname is entered in PATH_SRC_DATUM.

Help.Tip: Whether to use constant receiver datum or datum file.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_REC_DATUM
Whether to use constant receiver datum or datum file.
 
 Default = CONSTANT
 Allowed = PATH
 Allowed = CONSTANT
 
 If OPT_REC_DATUM = CONSTANT, then the constant receiver datum
 specified by parameter CONST_REC_DATUM will be used.
 
 If OPT_REC_DATUM = PATH, then define receiver datum by
 file whose pathname is entered in PATH_REC_DATUM.

Help.Tip: Constant source datum value.
Help.Text:
kdmig - CONST_SRC_DATUM
