Constant source datum value.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real
 CONST_SRC_DATUM should be set to the average source datum elevation for
 input data after statics shift.  Use PATH_SRC_DATUM if the source datum
 varies significantly in elevation.
 
 Active if PATH_SRC_DATUM = NONE.

Help.Tip: Constant receiver datum value.
Help.Text:
kdmig - CONST_REC_DATUM
Constant receiver datum value.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real
 CONST_REC_DATUM should be set to the average receiver datum elevation for
 input data after statics shift.  Use PATH_REC_DATUM if the receiver datum
 varies significantly in elevation.
 
 Active if PATH_REC_DATUM = NONE.

Help.Tip: src_datum path name.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SELECT_PATH_SRC_DATUM
src_datum path name.

Help.Tip: Pathname for source datum file.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PATH_SRC_DATUM
Pathname for source datum file.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character
 PATH_SRC_DATUM is the pathname of a file containing variable source datum
 elevation values.  Use CONST_SRC_DATUM if the source datum does not vary
 significantly in elevation.
 
 If PATH_SRC_DATUM = NONE, CONST_SRC_DATUM will be active.

Help.Tip: rec_datum path name.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SELECT_PATH_REC_DATUM
rec_datum path name.

Help.Tip: Pathname for receiver datum file.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PATH_REC_DATUM
Pathname for receiver datum file.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character
 PATH_REC_DATUM is the pathname of a file containing variable receiver datum
 elevation values.  Use CONST_REC_DATUM if the receiver datum does not vary
 significantly in elevation.
 
 If PATH_REC_DATUM = NONE, CONST_REC_DATUM will be active.

Help.Tip: Raytrace time increment option.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_RAY_INC
Raytrace time increment option.
 
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 Default = CONSTANT  use constant.
 Allowed = READ      read from file
 Allowed = WRITE     compute and write to file
 Allowed = COMPUTE   compute only.
 
 During raytracing KMIG shoots rays in a series of stages.
 The first two stages are the micro step and micro step.
 Each ray is handled separately during the micro and macro stages.
 
 Each macro step consists of several micro steps.
 
 During a single micro step the ray position and ray parameter is
 extrapolated out a micro time step distance from intial ray location
 using the ray parameter and velocity at the ray location at the start
 of the micro step.
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC = CONSTANT the value of the micro ray step length
 is kept constant throughout the velocity model and for all rays.
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC is not CONSTANT the value of the micro ray step length
 is varies throughout the velocity model with a resultant efficiency
 improvement.
 
 The size of the variable ray time step length is controled by parameter
 RAY_TIM_ACCURACY.  Decreasing RAY_TIM_ACCURACY will cause KMIG to
 take smaller ray time steps when the velocity field varies rapidly.
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC = READ the value of the variable ray time step length
 read from a precomputed data file stored in the file PATH_RAY_INC
 at the model input stage,
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC = COMPUTE or WRITE the value of the variable ray time
 step length is precomputed just before the first travel time table
 is computed.
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC = WRITE the value of the variable ray time
 is written to the file PATH_RAY_INC for later reuse.
 
 The algorithm for computing the variable ray time step length follows:
 
 RAY_TIM_INC is the minimum micro ray step in seconds.
 RAY_MICRO_RATIO is the nominal number of ray micro steps per macro time step.
 
 For each input velocity node KMIG shoots a series of isotropic test rays
 at a variety of angles with different micro ray step lengths of
 I * RAY_TIM_INC where I varies from 1 to RAY_MICRO_RATIO.
 
 It then computes RAY_TIM_DIFFERENCE (I) = the time distance between the
 endpoints of of the ray shot with a ray time step length of
 I * RAY_TIM_INC .
 
 KMIG looks through all the test rays and finds the largest I index
 for which the maximum value of RAY_TIM_DIFFERENC(I) <= RAY_TIM_ACCURACY.
 
 Note:
 
 The I = 1 ray is considered to be the most accurate because it samples
 the field velocity most finely and is the default setting for the ray time
 step length if OPT_RAY_INC = CONSTANT.
 
 The I = RAY_MICRO_RATIO ray is considered to be the least accurate because
 it samples the field velocity most coarsely.

Help.Tip: Ray inc path name.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SELECT_PATH_RAY_INC
Ray inc path name.

Help.Tip: Pathname of ray inc file.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PATH_RAY_INC
Pathname of ray inc file.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character

Help.Tip: Method used for raytracing.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_RAY
Method used for raytracing.
 
 Default = SHORTEST
 Allowed = ENERGETIC  (most energetic  - will greatly increase cpu time.)
 Allowed = FIRST      (first arrival)
 Allowed = SHORTEST   (shortest raypath)
 Allowed = VELOCITY   (smallest maximum velocity)
 Allowed = LAST       (longest time)
 Allowed = LONGEST    (longest raypath)

Help.Tip: Raytrace gradient option.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_RAY_GRAD
Raytrace gradient option.
 
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 Default = VELOCITY  Interpolate velocity.
 Allowed = SLOWNESS  Interpolate slowness.
 
 If OPT_RAY_GRAD = VELOCITY all ray traceing velocity gradient computations
 assume linear velocity between model x,y,z nodes.
 
 This will produce slightly different same travel times for velocity models
 that repesent the same velocity variation but have different
 sampling characteristics.
 
 This is the original KMIG assumption for ray tracing and is not consistent
 with other travel time table computation methods.
 
 If OPT_RAY_GRAD = SLOWNESS all ray traceing velocity gradient computations
 assume linear slowness between model x,y,z nodes.
 
 This is the original KMIG assumption regarding velocity variation and is
 consistent with other travel time table computation methods.
 
 This will produce the same travel times for velocity models
 that repesent the same velocity variation but have different
 sampling characteristics.
 
 Note, amplitude computations which depend upon the second derivitive of the
 velocity with respect to x,y,z are still done assuming linear velocity
 variations.

Help.Tip: Raytrace coefficient interpolation.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_RAY_STEP
Raytrace coefficient interpolation.
 
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 Default = VELOCITY  interpolate velocity.
 Allowed = SLOWNESS  interpolate slowness.
 
 If OPT_RAY_STEP = CONSTANT all ray time to distance computations
 assume constant velocity at the ray start point.
 This is the original method use dby KMIG for computing ray step lengths.
 
 If OPT_RAY_STEP = GRADIENT all ray time to distance computations
 assume linear velocity between model x,y,z nodes.
 This corrects for a slight variation in the computed travel times
 as a function of the ray step length.

Help.Tip: Raytrace ray bending option.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_RAY_BEND
Raytrace ray bending option.
 
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 Default = START   Use the velocity gradient at the start of the ray step.
 Allowed = END     Use the velocity gradient at the end of the ray step.
 Allowed = AVERAGE Use the average velocity gradient overf the ray step.
 
 If OPT_RAY_BEND = START all ray bending computations
 use the velocity gradient at the start of the ray step.
 This is the original method use dby KMIG for computing ray bending.
 
 If OPT_RAY_BEND = END all ray bending computations
 use the velocity gradient at the end of the ray step.
 
 If OPT_RAY_BEND = AVERAGE all ray bending computations
 use the velocity gradient average at the start and end of the ray step.
 This is probably the most correct method for computing ray bending.

Help.Tip: Maximum number of rays to trace at any time step.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_MAX_NUMBER
Maximum number of rays to trace at any time step.
 
 Default = 30001
 Allowed = int > 0

Help.Tip: Ray time accuracy limit in seconds.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_TIM_ACCURACY
Ray time accuracy limit in seconds.
 
 Default = .001
 Allowed = 0 <= real
 Ray time accuracy limit for variable ray step length ray tracing.
 During raytracing KMIG shoots rays in a series of stages.
 The first two stages are the micro step and micro step.
 Each ray is handled separately during the micro and macro stages.
 
 Each macro step consists of several micro steps.
 
 During a single micro step the ray position and ray parameter is
 extrapolated out a micro time step distance from intial ray location
 using the ray parameter and velocity at the ray location at the start
 of the micro step.
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC = CONSTANT the value of the micro ray step length
 is kept constant throughout the velocity model and for all rays.
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC is not CONSTANT the value of the micro ray step length
 is varies throughout the velocity model with a resultant efficiency
 improvement.
 
 The size of the variable ray time step length is controled by parameter
 RAY_TIM_ACCURACY.  Decreasing RAY_TIM_ACCURACY will cause KMIG to
 take smaller ray time steps when the velocity field varies rapidly.
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC = READ the value of the variable ray time step length
 read from a precomputed data file stored in the file PATH_RAY_INC
 at the model input stage,
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC = COMPUTE or WRITE the value of the variable ray time
 step length is precomputed just before the first travel time table
 is computed.
 
 If OPT_RAY_INC = WRITE the value of the variable ray time
 is written to the file PATH_RAY_INC for later reuse.
 
 The algorithm for computing the variable ray time step length follows:
 
 RAY_TIM_INC is the minimum micro ray step in seconds.
 RAY_MICRO_RATIO is the nominal number of ray micro steps per macro time step.
 
 For each input velocity node KMIG shoots a series of isotropic test rays
 at a variety of angles with different micro ray step lengths of
 I * RAY_TIM_INC where I varies from 1 to RAY_MICRO_RATIO.
 
 It then computes RAY_TIM_DIFFERENCE (I) = the time distance between the
 endpoints of of the ray shot with a ray time step length of
 I * RAY_TIM_INC .
 
 KMIG looks through all the test rays and finds the largest I index
 for which the maximum value of RAY_TIM_DIFFERENC(I) <= RAY_TIM_ACCURACY.
 
 Note:
 
 The I = 1 ray is considered to be the most accurate because it samples
 the field velocity most finely and is the default setting for the ray time
 step length if OPT_RAY_INC = CONSTANT.
 
 The I = RAY_MICRO_RATIO ray is considered to be the least accurate because
 it samples the field velocity most coarsely.

Help.Tip: Ray interpolation factor.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_INTERPOLATION
Ray interpolation factor.
 
 Default = 10
 Allowed = int > 0
 New rays are interpolated between old rays every RAY_INTERPOLATION macro
 time steps.  Making this larger will reduce the CPU requirements and accuracy.

Help.Tip: Number of ray micro time steps in a macro time step.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_MICRO_RATIO
Number of ray micro time steps in a macro time step.
 
 Default = 5
 Allowed = int > 0
 Ray information is extrapolated in micro time step intervals.
 Rays are interpolated to the table every RAY_MICRO_RATIO micro time steps.
 When using variable ray time step lengths this is a upper limit.

Help.Tip: Maximum ray separation for ray tracing, in distance units.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_COMP_INC
Maximum ray separation for ray tracing, in distance units.
 
 Default = -1 = compute
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 If parameter TYPE_TABLE_CALC is set to RAYTRACE, RAYTRVTI,
 VOFZ, or STRAIGHT,
 then RAY_COMP_INC determines the maximum ray separation
 increment used between successive computational points in the ray tracing
 calculations. The default value of -1 causes this distance to be computed.

Help.Tip: Ray stopping angle in degrees.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_MAX_ANGLE
Ray stopping angle in degrees.
 
 Default = 135.
 Allowed = 0 <= real <=180
 Maximum ray turning angle from the Z axis in degrees.
 Rays that turn beyond this angle are stopped. Use 90. or greater.

Help.Tip: Ray tube to grid node interpolation option
Help.Text:
kdmig - OPT_RAY_FILL
Ray tube to grid node interpolation option
 
 Default = OLD
 Allowed = OLD     The original average surrounding time algorithm.
 Allowed = AVERAGE The revised  average surrounding time algorithm.
 Allowed = EIKONAL Crude EIKONAL solution.

Help.Tip: Ray tube fill scale factor.
Help.Text:
kdmig - SCALE_RAY_FILL
Ray tube fill scale factor.
 
 Default = 2.
 Allowed = real
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 If any ray tube side dimension exceeds SCALE_RAY_FILL * TABLE_COMP_INC
 the ray tube segment will not be used to fill in table nodes.

Help.Tip: Maximum number of micro ray time steps.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_TIM_TOT
Maximum number of micro ray time steps.
 
 Default = NDPT/5
 Allowed = real > 0.

Help.Tip: Initial number of rays for the angle measured from the z axis.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_ANG1_TOT
Initial number of rays for the angle measured from the z axis.
 
 Default = -1
 Allowed = int
 If RAY_ANG1 < 0 the ANG1 coefficients will be set to the defaults
 For DIMENSON = 2D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 91
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = -90.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.
 For DIMENSON = 3D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 46
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = 0.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.

Help.Tip: Initial number of rays for the angle measured around the z axis.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_ANG2_TOT
Initial number of rays for the angle measured around the z axis.
 
 Default = 181
 Allowed = int > 0
 If RAY_ANG1 < 0 the ANG1 coefficients will be set to the defaults
 For DIMENSON = 2D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 91
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = -90.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.
 For DIMENSON = 3D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 46
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = 0.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.

Help.Tip: Initial ray time value in seconds.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_TIM_INIT
Initial ray time value in seconds.
 
 Default = 0.00005
 Allowed = real >= 0
 This should be a small non zero number.

Help.Tip: Minimum ray angle for the angle measured from the z axis.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_ANG1_INIT
Minimum ray angle for the angle measured from the z axis.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = 0 <= real <= 360.
 If RAY_ANG1 < 0 the ANG1 coefficients will be set to the defaults
 For DIMENSON = 2D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 91
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = -90.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.
 For DIMENSON = 3D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 46
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = 0.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.

Help.Tip: Minimum ray angle for the angle measured around the z axis.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_ANG2_INIT
Minimum ray angle for the angle measured around the z axis.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = 0 <= real <= 360.

Help.Tip: Maximum ray time value in seconds.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_TIM_LAST
Maximum ray time value in seconds.
 
 Default = (NDPT-1)*DT+TSTRT
 Allowed = real > RAY_TIM_INIT

Help.Tip: Maximum ray angle for the angle measured from the z axis.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_ANG1_LAST
Maximum ray angle for the angle measured from the z axis.
 
 Default = 90
 Allowed = 0 <= real <= 360.
 If RAY_ANG1 < 0 the ANG1 coefficients will be set to the defaults
 For DIMENSON = 2D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 91
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = -90.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.
 For DIMENSON = 3D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 46
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = 0.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.

Help.Tip: Maximum ray angle for the angle measured around the z axis.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_ANG2_LAST
Maximum ray angle for the angle measured around the z axis.
 
 Default = 360
 Allowed = 0 <= real <= 360.

Help.Tip: Time length of micro ray step in seconds.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_TIM_INC
Time length of micro ray step in seconds.
 
 Default = 5*DT
 Allowed = real
 Not used for time migration and DMO.
 When using variable ray time step lengths this is a lower limit.

Help.Tip: Ray angle increment for the angle measured from the z axis.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_ANG1_INC
Ray angle increment for the angle measured from the z axis.
 
 Default = 2
 Allowed = 0 <= real <= 360.
 If RAY_ANG1 < 0 the ANG1 coefficients will be set to the defaults
 For DIMENSON = 2D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 91
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = -90.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.
 For DIMENSON = 3D :
                     RAY_ANG1_TOT  = 46
                     RAY_ANG1_INIT = 0.
                     RAY_ANG1_LAST = +90.
                     RAY_ANG1_INC  = 2.

Help.Tip: Ray angle increment for the angle measured around the z axis.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RAY_ANG2_INC
Ray angle increment for the angle measured around the z axis.
 
 Default = 2
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: Button that removes this process parameter screen.
Help.Text:
kdmig - CLOSE
Button that removes this process parameter screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Appears only on the view-only process parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
Help.Text:
kdmig - OK
Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values, runs the parameter traps and removes
 the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
Help.Text:
kdmig - APPLY
Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps but does
 not remove the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
Help.Text:
kdmig - CANCEL
Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =

Help.Tip: Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
Help.Text:
kdmig - RESET
Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that sets the parameters back to their values when the screen appeared
 or to their last applied value.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PROCESSLISTLEFT
Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the previous process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PROCESSLIST
Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Menu that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to any chosen process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PROCESSLISTRIGHT
Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the next process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
Help.Text:
kdmig - PROJECTDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as Project Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of Project Defaults for a project.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
Help.Text:
kdmig - USERDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as User Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of User Defaults for a userid.

Help.Tip: Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
Help.Text:
kdmig - HELP
Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 The Help Window allows access to three kinds of help:  Parameter Help, CPS
 Process Help and Application (CFE) Help.

<html><head><base href=file:///usr/app/vendors/int/Conoco/xml/help/> <pre>------------------------------------------------------------------------------- C P S P R O C E S S
Name : KDMIG (Kirchhoff Depth MIGration) Category : Migrations Written : 2001-09-14 by: Stephen Chiu Revised : 2006-08-29 by: D. Glover Maturity : production Purpose : 2D and 3D Kirchhoff depth migration. Portability: No known limitations. Parallel : YES
------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- GENERAL DESCRIPTION
KDMIG is a general 2D or 3D Kirchhoff DEPTH migration process that will operate in either the migrate or the model direction.
Coordinates
HDR_X and HDR_Y define the header words used as coordinates for input traces and the OUTPUT image volume. Allowed values for HDR_X and HDR_Y are (7,8); (8,7); (17,18) or (18,17) only. KDMIG always determines the offset of input traces from header word 6.
If HDR_X and HDR_Y = 7,8 or 8,7 (grid coordinates), then KDMIG uses input trace header words 7 and 8 for midpoint and 33, 34, 35 and 36 for azimuth. Header words 17 and 18 for output traces are calculated using the CPS grid transform.
If HDR_X and HDR_Y = 17,18 or 18,17 (surveyed coordinates), then KDMIG uses input trace header words 17 and 18 for midpoint and 11, 12, 14 and 15 for azimuth. Header words 7 and 8 for output traces are calculated using the CPS grid transform.
Nominal Output Image Volume
Trace image-point locations in the nominal OUTPUT image volume are specified by the parameters HDR_X, X_INIT, X_INC, X_LAST, X_TOT and similar parameters for the y-coordinate. Additional parameters specify the depth and offset dimensions of the nominal output image volume.
Input trace midpoints need not agree exactly with trace locations defined by the nominal output image volume.
The output image volume defined by the x-coordinate, y-coordinate, depth and offset parameters is the NOMINAL output image volume. Depending on the values assigned to the ALL_OUT, POLYGON and SPARSE parameters and input trace offset values, the traces actually output may be a subset of the nominal output image volume.
Output Images and Offset Bins
The parameters OFF_INIT, OFF_INC, OFF_LAST and OFF_TOT define a set of offset bins.
If ONE_IMAGE = NO, then:
1. Each KDMIG output image is associated with an offset bin. Header word 6 for output traces is set to the associated offset bin center value.
2. KDMIG migrates each offset bin separately, that is, only input traces with header word 6 within a particular offset bin contribute to the output image associated with that offset bin.
3. The current image is output and a new one started whenever the input trace stream changes to a different offset bin.
4. Output images are produced only for those offset bins that are occupied by input traces.
5. Input traces with offset outside the range of the offset bins are ignored.
If ONE_IMAGE = YES, then:
1. Only a single image is produced regardless of input trace offset.
2. Header word 6 for output traces is set to the center value of the offset bin associated with the offset of the first input trace. The imaging aperture is determined by this same offset bin.
ONE_IMAGE = YES should only be used if virtually all input traces have offset that lies within the offset bin associated with the first input trace.
Aperture Specification
The AP_X_MAX and AP_Y_MAX parameters specify the size of a rectangular aperture, centered on the input trace midpoint. No imaging will occur beyond this aperture regardless of other parameter values.
Additionally a depth dependent elliptical aperture is defined in the horizontal plane with foci at the source and receiver locations. The semi-major axis (parallel to the source-receiver direction) is given by offset/2 + AP_X(depth), where AP_X is depth dependent. The semi-minor axis (perpendicular to the source-receiver direction) is given by AP_Y(depth), where AP_Y is depth dependent.
In any azimuthal direction from the input trace midpoint, no imaging will occur outside the closer of either the rectangular or the elliptical aperture.
Three sets of aperture parameters are available, allowing you to specify aperture in distance (feet or meters), grid units (units of header words 7 and 8) or angle in degrees.
Filter
KDMIG applies a filter to the input traces to correct for the effect of the Kirchhoff sum. This filter has a (frequency ** PWR_FILT) component and a phase rotation component. Theoretical values of PWR_FILT are 0.5 for 2D and 1.0 for 3D. Theoretical values of PHASE_FILT are 45 degrees for 2D and 90 degrees for 3D. Lower values of PWR_FILT emphasize low frequencies, higher values of PWR_FILT emphasize high frequencies. Adjusting the PWR_FILT value allows you to adjust the image frequency balance and the apparent amount of noise in the image. This may be desirable for some datasets.
Anti-aliasing Filter
Parameters ALIAS_LENGTH and DIST_AA define the operator antialiasing filter applied during migration.
ALIAS_LENGTH is the maximum length of the alias filter in interpolated input time samples, 31 is normal. DIST_AA is the average separation of input traces in distance units.
KDMIG uses the Claerbout integration method for operator anti-aliasing which images a filtered version of the input trace. As the dip of the summation trajectory through the input data increases, KDMIG uses a wider filter yielding a lower frequency input trace. The apporpriate filter width is a function of the input trace spacing, the separation between input and output traces, the input and output times, which in turn are functions of the velocity field.
Using a larger value of DIST_AA results in more filtering and lower frequencies in the output image. Using a smaller value of DIST_AA results in less filtering and higher frequencies which may contain some aliased noise. Using DIST_AA = 0. turns off the aliasing completely.
This operator anti-aliasing filter is a centered summation of the interpolated input trace using a triangular summation weight which is 1. at the center of the filter and 0. and both ends. The summation is normalized by the triangular area.
For efficiency KDMIG constructs a different copy of the input trace for each possible filter length. The maximum half-length of the filter is ALIAS_LENGTH interpolated input time samples long. (Recall that the input trace is interpolated by a factor of DT_INTERP to a finer time scale to allow nearest neighbor interpolation.)
Using a value of ALIAS_LENGTH that is too small may restrict KDMIG to too short a maximum filter length which allows some aliased energy to pass. Using a value which is too large may cause KDMIG to spend too much time precomputing the filtered traces. (This CPU time is indicated in the .rpt file.) ALIAS_LENGTH = 30 is usually sufficient, ALIAS_LENGTH = 40 is probably excessive and ALIAS_LENGTH = 20 too small.
To determine resonable values for ALIAS_LENGTH and DIST_AA I recommend you select a constant value of DIST_AA equal to an average input trace spacing, and conduct a series of impulse response tests with different ALIAS_LENGTH and DIST_AA values using an output trace spacing equal to the original DIST_AA and look for visual aliasing. If visual aliasing exists you would want to increase either ALIAS_LENGTH, DIST_AA or both.
Increasing DIST_AA from the original value selected multiplies the effective distance between output traces (DIST_AA) prior to calculating the anti-alias operator. Values of DIST_AA range from 0.0 (no anti-aliasing) to 2.0 (double anti-aliasing) times the nominal DIST_AA value.
Note this only accounts for the operator or summation aliasing effects. It does not acount for apparent visual inherent in the choice of output space and time sampling.
Amplitude Balance and Stack Scaling
Because aperture usually increases with trace time, an output trace usually receives contributions from fewer input traces shallow and from more traces deep. This may cause an amplitude imbalance on output traces. A fold of stack scaling can be applied to compensate for this imbalance. Fold of stack scaling divides the composited output trace sample value by the local fold raised to a power.
Normally fold of stack scaling is disabled in KDMIG and any output amplitude imbalance is corrected using a process such as MVXP, DBGAIN, TPOW or EXO.
Offset-depth Mute
The OFFSETS and DEP_OFF linked arrays constitute a depth-offset mute for KDMIG. This mute determines what input trace offsets can contribute to the image traces at a given depth. For a given OFFSETS-DEP_OFF pair, the OFFSETS value is the maximum input trace offset that can contribute to an image trace at a depth given by the DEP_OFF value. Typically OFFSETS values increase as DEP_OFF values increase. This constraint is in addition to the restriction imposed by the aperture parameters.
The depth-offset mute can help eliminate artifacts caused by non-physical mapping. A stronger mute will reduce run-time.
Diagnostic Output
KDMIG can produce diagnostic outputs of velocity, two-way travel time, amplitude factor or anti-alias coefficient if the appropriate option is selected in OPT_OUTPUT. When producing diagnostic outputs, a single trace should be input and ALL_OUT set to YES. Output trace samples will be dead outside the specified aperture.
For normal imaging operation, set OPT_OUTPUT to IMAGE.
Polygons
The polygon parameters allow you to define one or more closed polygons on the x-y image plane. If one or more polygons are defined, then imaging is performed only to traces within the polygons or on a polygon boundary. All traces in the coordinate volume will be output, but those outside the polygons will be dead.
Polygons can be specified with the X_POLY, Y_POLY and ID_POLY linked array parameters. X and Y coordinates for a vertex are specified by X_POLY and Y_POLY.
1. All vertices for a single polygon must be entered sequentially (clockwise or counterclockwise).
2. All vertices for a single polygon must be in consecutive rows.
3. All vertices for a single polygon must have the same value of ID_POLY.
4. Different polygons must have different values of ID_POLY (starting with 1 and incrementing by 1).
Alternatively, polygons can be specified by a polygon file. Polygon files are ascii files whose first three columns carry the same information as X_POLY, Y_POLY and ID_POLY respectively and can have an optional fourth column carrying header value information. Only the first three columns are used by KDMIG.
The SETPOLY CPS process requires polygon files with four columns. Files prepared for SETPOLY can be used with KDMIG, although the fourth column will be ignored.
Sparse Output
It is often desirable to output a few lines or scattered CIPs rather than the entire nominal image volume. The sparse output option allows you to define one or more distinct grids of output traces where each such grid is a subset of the nominal image volume.
The first row of the SP_X parameter linked arrays defines a set of HDR_X values and the first row of the SP_Y parameter linked arrays defines a set of HDR_Y values. This row defines a grid of output traces whose imagepoints have the HDR_X and HDR_Y values in common. (Output trace imagepoints are the intersection of the HDR_X and HDR_Y values specified in the first row.)
Each additional row of the SP_X and SP_Y parameter linked arrays defines a separate grid of output trace locations.
The sparse output volume is the union of all of the grids defined by the entries in the SP_X and SP_Y parameter linked arrays.
HDR_X and HDR_Y values specified by the sparse output parameters must agree exactly with trace locations defined by the nominal output image volume.
Parallelization
Parameters NUM_CPUS, PAR_GROUPS and DIV_TYPE are for parallel processing.
KDMIG associates worker CPUs into PAR_GROUPS number of independent CPU groups.
1. The input dataset is partitioned into PAR_GROUPS distinct subsets, with each group receiving one subset of the input dataset.
2. All CPUs within a group receive the same input traces.
3. Each group has its own entire image volume that is separate from the image volumes associated with other groups.
4. The image volume for each group is partitioned into subsets with one subset for each CPU. Each CPU will image only to the image subset with which it is associated.
5. DIV_TYPE is the X node distribution over PES. KDMIG will divide the x image nodes between processors in a group.
Each group should have the same number of CPUs, NUM_CPUS. The number of worker CPUs in the job should be a multiple of PAR_GROUPS. The number of CPUs in the job is 1 + the number of worker CPUs in the job.)
If PAR_GROUPS = 1, then all worker CPUs contribute to a single common image.
If PAR_GROUPS = number of worker CPUs, then each CPU produces an image independent of the other CPUs and these separate images are composited by KDMIG to form the output.
Anisotropic Options
Three options are available for anisotropic depth migration.
If OPT_ANISO = ISOTROPIC, then an isotropic method is used.
If OPT_ANISO = ANISOTROPIC, then a vertical transverse isotropic (VTI) method is used.
If OPT_ANISO = TILTED_BED, then a tilted bed transverse isotropic method is used.
The anisotropic methods can be used only if OPT_TABLE = EIKONAL.
Travel Time Tables
Travel time tables are calculated and saved on a coarse horizontal XY grid defined in the x-direction by TABLE_X_INIT, TABLE_X_INC, TABLE_X_LAST and TABLE_X_TOT and by similar parameters in the y-direction. (Typically if HDR_X and HDR_Y are 7,8 or 8,7 then TABLE_X_INC and TABLE_Y_INC are set to 4 or 5.)
Because input traces lying outside the range of this travel time table grid will have travel times that are ill-defined, the travel time table grid should cover the entire XY range of the input data.
The travel times that are actually used for imaging a trace are interpolated from entries in the four tables that surround the trace on the coarse grid.
Each individual travel time table contains travel times corresponding to different values of depth and aperture. The depth values for travel time table entries are given by the AP_DEP_INIT, AP_DEP_INC, AP_DEP_LAST and AP_DEP_TOT parameters. (Typically AP_DEP_INC is set to 5 * DEP_INC.)
The aperture values used for the travel time table entries are determined in the x-direction by AP_X_MAX (the maximum aperture), AP_X_INC (the aperture spacing between travel time calculations) and OFF_X_MAX (the maximum offset) and similarly in the y-direction.
Larger values of TABLE_X_INC, TABLE_Y_INC, AP_X_INC, AP_Y_INC and AP_DEP_INC reduce CPU time and memory requirement but decrease accuracy.
Datum Parameters
In land processing, statics shifts are applied to traces so that sources and receivers are shifted to a new datum (generally not the surface). Usually land data being processed for depth migration is shifted to a floating datum. The KDMIG datum parameters should be set to the datum of the source and receiver after any static shift has been applied.
If this datum has a small variation in elevation, the CONST_SRC_DATUM and CONST_REC_DATUM parameters can be used to specify an average datum. If the datum has a substantial variation in elevation, the PATH_SRC_DATUM and PATH_REC_DATUM parameters should be used (these specify files containing variable datum elevations).
If PATH_SRC_DATUM = NONE, source datum information is provided to KDMIG by the CONST_SRC_DATUM parameter. Otherwise, the PATH_SRC_DATUM parameter provides source datum information to KDMIG. (And similarly for receivers.)
Datum parameter values are used in anti-aliasing and other operations.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ADVICE FOR USERS
General
HDR_X and HDR_Y will normally be 7,8 (or 8,7).
If HDR_X and HDR_Y = 7,8 (or 8,7), then header words 7, 8, 33, 34, 35 and 36 on input traces must NOT be integerized (rounded).
If HDR_X and HDR_Y = 17,18 (or 18,17), then header words 17, 18, 11, 12, 14 and 15 on input traces must NOT be integerized (rounded).
The CPS grid transform must be set properly in CFE.
All CPUs in a parallel job should have the same speed.
Units
If HDR_X and HDR_Y = 7,8 (or 8,7), then HDR_X and HDR_Y units are grid units, defined by the CFE grid transform.
If HDR_X and HDR_Y = 17,18 (or 18,17), then HDR_X and HDR_Y units are physical distance units (feet or meters).
All times are in seconds. Depth units are physical distance units (feet or meters). Velocity units must be consistent (feet/sec or meters/sec). All offset units are feet or meters. All angle units are degrees.
The DEP_SCALE parameter is used to scale the vertical image dimension to output traces so that:
Output TSTRT = DEP_INIT / DEP_SCALE. Output DT = DEP_INC / DEP_SCALE.
2D vs. 3D
If DIMENSION = 2D, then a 2D algorithm is used, all "X" parameters pertain to the inline direction, all "Y" parameters are ignored and the aperture has extent in the inline direction only. Only one 2D line can be migrated at once.
If DIMENSION = 3D, then a 3D algorithm is used and both "X" parameters and "Y" parameters are active.
PWR_FILT and PHASE_FILT have different default values for 2D and for 3D; be sure to set them properly.
Input Trace Offset and Sort Order
Input data should always be sorted to common offsets.
For 3D before-stack work: Usually one offset at a time is migrated and ONE_IMAGE is set to YES so that input traces with offset values at a bin edge do not trigger a new image.
For 2D before-stack work: Usually ONE_IMAGE is set to NO and the entire line is migrated at once. In this case input traces occupying a new offset bin will trigger the start of a new image.
Output Trace Sort Order
Sort order of output traces from fastest to slowest:
If SORT_ORDER = X_IS FAST: Index of TABLE_FCTR array, HDR_X, HDR_Y, offset bin as occupied.
If SORT_ORDER = Y_IS FAST: Index of TABLE_FCTR array, HDR_Y, HDR_X, offset bin as occupied.
It may be necessary to sort output traces to the desired order.
Before Stack vs. After Stack Migration
For after stack (zero-offset) migration using KDMIG the offset header word of input traces should be set to zero and you should set ONE_IMAGE = YES, OFF_TOT = 1 and OFF_INIT = 0.0. For before stack migration, the offset parameters should be set to define the desired offset bins.
